Ottawa, August 15, 1934.

Sir:

An officer of the Department recently visited the Caughnawaga Bush School and it was found that the cover on the well is unsafe. It was also noted that there was considerable loose lumber around the school.

The Department considers that the janitor, Michael O. Phillips, should repair the cover on the well, in order to make it safe for anyone to walk over. Mr. and Mrs. Phillips are being well treated by the Department, and it is considered that Phillips should do this work without charge.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKensie,
Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, P.Q.
Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of 26th May last and to ask you whether the repairs to the stable and the fence at the Caughnawaga Bush School are intended to be carried out before the re-opening of the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, August 22nd, 1934.

Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the repairs to the stable and fence at the Caughnawaga Bush Indian Day School.

As the stable is used for animals owned by the teacher, it is considered that she should arrange for any repairs required, without cost to the Department.

Regarding the fence, it is considered that the janitor of this school should do the necessary repairs without extra remuneration.

As pointed out in official letter of the 18th instant, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips are being well treated by this Department and it is considered that he should look after minor repairs without extra charge.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.
Dear Sir,

It was a shock for me to learn that my School Return did not reach you, and I can explain nothing in regard to it except that I gave it in to Sr. Mary Frances, Superior at the convent, the end of June, as I always do.

Sr. Mary Francis has since been replaced and I could get no further information about it. But several of the sisters remember well my giving it in. It is a mystery to me, and regret the inconvenience it has caused you. I am sending another in case you don't come across the original.

In regard to repairs on premises, which I must impress.

Aug. 28, 1934

CANADA
you that they are in bad condition. I also wish to draw your attention to Mr. Phillips as janitor. We had no idea we had to do all repairs on our salary. Though I must say he has done much repairing. Whatever he could do he has done. For instance the fence. He has fixed it so often now that it is so rusty it breaks right in his hands. Of course too, we understand times are hard, and Mr. Phillips is ready to repair the fence without cost but he must have new wire.

The well too is unsafe. Mr. Phillips thought a cement platform would be stronger, safer, and more permanent than lumber. But if you find it too much for you, he'll fix it the way you want it.
By the way, the loose lumber your man saw is lumber bought by Mr. Phillips when they tore some buildings done at Nelson. He bought it to make a shelter for his car and some vehicles for the winter.

Though the stable was in bad condition when we came, Mr. Phillips thinks if we put off repairing it now, there won't be much chance of saving it later. That is why he asked to have it raised. It has caused him a lot of trouble as the building has sunk deep and in the spring when there is so much water it is always flooded, and speeds the decay. Of course he'll do what he can, but he doesn't see how he can have it
raised without cost, so I guess he will will leave that part of it out.

Though we earn a salary we too, sometimes feel the depression, as we pay a good sum out for things I think necessary, yet cannot get otherwise, as to prizes for the children, Christmas tree and an occasional thorough cleaning of the school, and closets. I am telling you this not because I regret it, but because we don't want you to think us so very hard and selfish, and we are grateful.

Yours Sincerely,
Mary K. Phillips
Teacher.

Ottawa, July 20, 1935.

Sir:

I enclose herewith an account to the amount of $60 for laundry services for the teachers' residence and school on the Caughnawaga Reserve for the months of April, May and June, last. If you consider this account is in order, you should attach same to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

I am also returning the account which you forwarded in favour of Michael O. Phillips, which you state is for services rendered during the past school year at the Caughnawaga Eastern School. Should not this be for the Bush School? The janitor of the Bush School is Mrs. Phillips, who is allowed payment at the rate of $35 per year. It was understood that this amount was to cover the cost of cleaning the closets. In any event, it is considered that the amount charged, viz., $5 per closet, is too high.

Regarding the wood, this school is furnished with coke, and it is not understood why wood should have been supplied, except, possibly, a small quantity of kindling wood.

The Department would like further information regarding the items on the voucher.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

Caughnawaga, August 1st, 1935.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo, returning me the account forwarded in favour of Michael O. Phillips, for services rendered during the past school year at the Caughnawaga Bush School, as janitor at the rate of $35 a year. This account was also covering the cleaning of three closets at $6 each and including a charge of $20 for five cords of wood. You stated in your letter that the cost of cleaning the closets, viz., $5 per closet, was considered too high. Regarding the wood, you pointed out that the school was furnished with coke and that it was not understood why such a large quantity of wood was supplied.

In reply, I beg to say that I interviewed Mr. and Mrs. Phillips who claimed that the Department has for several years been paying $5 for the cleaning of the closets, once a year. As this charge used to be considered as extra work, owing to the fact that the salary of janitor was only of $35, these people are claiming that they will not accept any amount less than $5 for this kind of work. Relative to the supplying of wood, I beg to say that they claim to have used the five cords of wood as kindling wood. They stated that since they are supplied with coke instead of coal, they are using more kindling wood.

I would recommend that the charge of $5 for the closets be reduced at $2.50 and that only three cords of wood be paid out, as it is considered that three cords of kindling wood is sufficient for the need of the school. I would also ask you to send me a communication stating if you are willing to pay an additional amount for the cleaning of the closets for any school at Caughnawaga, if so, the price you intend to pay for such work. In the case of the kindling wood, I would suggest that no more than three cords a year be allowed for the Bush School.

I am returning you herewith the original account.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I'm taking the opportunity of informing you that the fence surrounding the Eastern Bush School is in very bad need of repairs. If anything, it is a pasture now and not a yard. It is very annoying, and is messed up by the cattle. It is impossible to keep it clean. I've asked for these repairs since I've been here. I hope you'll get tired of me and do something about it because I am rather a persevering person.

Hoping you will consider this at your earliest convenience. I beg to be

Sincerely,

Mrs. Mary R. Phillips,
Teacher
Ottawa, August 20, 1935.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, I beg to say that you may have the fence at the Bush School repaired. It is noted that the cost of the material will be approximately $42.

The work should be done by Mr. Robert, assisted by Joe Gatien and Michael O. Phillips.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Dep., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Bush School residence,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Mrs. John Bush, teacher at the above named School, has requested me to communicate with you in order to get authority for the purchase of a small cooking stove to be used at the residence of the School.

She states that the stove now in use at the residence is a combination of a heating and cooking stove and that it will be too warm for use in the summer and early in the Fall besides taking more fuel. She claims that she can get a small stove at J.A. Tessier, a dealer at 145 Notre-Dame st., Lachine, Que., for $20.00.

Will you be kind enough to let me know if this request can be considered so that I advise her accordingly.

(Frs. Brisebois)

I wish to inform that lighting struck both the Bush School
and the Teacher's residence of that same school recently.

The damage to the residence consist of only five or six feet
of the brick chimney which will have to be made anew and a few shingles
to the roof.

The school building suffered more damages. The chimney will

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, April 11, 1945.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

At Mr. Brisebois' request, we are writing to you regarding the Bush children that are being prepared for First Communion and for Confirmation; several of these children would necessarily have to be transported to the village every morning for two weeks' time at least, in order that they may follow the priest's instructions, rehearsals, etc., etc.

Last year, Father Lalonde managed to go for them every morning and to bring them back at night. However, as much as he would want to do it again this year, he cannot do so. This year marks the 100th anniversary of the present church and everything is being done to put Caughnawaga on the map. You probably will hear more of this with time. Our school children have been invited to present a pageant showing what the Department has done for the education of the Indians of Caughnawaga.

Would you approve our hiring some Indian to travel these children on those days when the R.C.M.P. will not be able to go for them with the sisters' car? Naturally, we cannot count only on the M.P.'s for they may be called at any time, for other work.

Thanking you for your kind attention to this matter, we beg to remain

Respectfully yours,

Sisters of Saint Ann

Principal.

Philip Phelan,

Caughnawaga, Que.,
April 5, 1946.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re:- Old stable at Caughnawaga
Bush School.

I wish to inform that the above stable which has not been used since many years is now unusable and is falling to pieces. Part of the roof is gone, the supporting beams have rotted away and the walls etc., are in a very bad condition. This stable is an eye sore and I would recommend that it be sold to a nearby indian farmer, Michael Day, who would give us the sum of TWENTY FIVE DOLLARS for it. Day would take the building down and would salvage whatever lumber that he could for use in repairing his own stable, and would clean the site.

May I say that even if a shed was needed at that School this building could not be utilized owing to its precarious condition.

Would you be kind enough to let me know if the above suggestion is acceptable to the Branch?

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 9, 1946.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT—

The Indian Day School known as "Bush School" is located about 4 miles from the village of Caughnawaga.

Many years ago a small stable was erected but this has not been used in recent years. Part of the roof is gone, supporting beams have rotted away and the walls, etc., are in very bad condition. This building is an eyesore and the Indian Agent recommends that it be sold to a nearby Indian farmer, named Michael Day, who is prepared to give us the sum of $25.00 for it. Day would take the building down and would clean the site. He would use the lumber for repairing his own stable.

Under the circumstances, I would appreciate having your authority to sell the building to Day at the price mentioned above.

Memorandum:

MR. BROWN
RESERVES AND TRUSTS DIVISION

Caughnawaga Bush Indian Day School

I inspected the school on the Caughnawaga Reserve last week and found that this building has been standing idle for some time. Both the school and teacherage are in good condition but will not be if they are left vacant for many more months. Mr. Brisebois advised me that there was some delay because of the fact that the title to the property was in doubt. Please find attached a Quit Claim Deed (Flag One) to the land which would seem to indicate that the property rests in the Crown and that we can dispose of it as we see fit.

My recommendation is that both the buildings and property of the Caughnawaga Bush School be declared surplus to the requirements of the Indian Affairs Branch and that tenders be called by your Division for the sale to an Indian or Indians.

Damage to Government Property,
Caughnawaga Bush School Teachers Residence,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

1. On 26-5-47 information was received from the office of the Indian agent here that someone had smashed the glass in the windows of the above named teachers residence.

2. On 29-5-47 in company with John Bush, caretaker, this writer patrolled on foot to the captioned noted place. It is situated on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, near the C.P.R. tracks some 2 miles south east of the village of Caughnawaga. The school and the teachers residence are two separate buildings and have been vacant and unused since June 1946. The area surrounding the school and teachers residence is farmland and there is only one family living within sight of the school and residence.

3. On arriving it was determined that considerable damage had been done to the aforesaid residence. Approximately 50 panes of glass, various sizes, had been smashed. As well, 6 lengths of stovepipe, 2 green window shades, 1 medicine cabinet and 1 small table had been destroyed. Some of the windows had been smashed from the outside and others from the inside. Entrance had been gained by forcing the rear door.

4. Enquiries were made at the home of Jimmie Jacobs who lives within sight of the school. They stated they believed the windows were intact on Sunday May 25th and first noticed they were smashed on Monday May 26th. They were not able to supply any information which would give indication of the party or parties responsible for the damages aforementioned. Two other farmers living some little distance from the school and residence, Mike Day and Frank Goodleaf were also interviewed. Neither was able to give any information as to who was responsible for the incident.

5. The investigation will be continued and some reliable contacts interviewed. Further report will be submitted to comply with the following D.D. 4-7-47.

Re Caughnawaga Reserve.

Ottawa, July 14th, 1903.

Reverend Dr. Griffith, in charge of Methodist Missions for the Montreal district, called yesterday to discuss matters in connection with the Methodist Church on the above reserve. He states that a church, school, residence and teacher are required and would like to know to what extent the Department is prepared to assist in this.

The Methodist Church will erect the church building but the Dr. thinks the Department should put up the other buildings and maintain the teacher.

I would like a full report on this, showing what churches, schools, residences, teachers, etc., there are now on the Caughnawaga Reserve and a statement in detail showing to what extent the Department is a contributor to the support of these, distinguishing between Band money and Departmental money.

Dr. Griffith's address is 17 St. Luke St., Montreal, Que., but he will go to Toronto at the end of this week and a letter addressed to him in care of Dr. R. C. Griffith, 12 Macdonnell Ave., Toronto, will reach him for a week or two afterwards.

D. S. G. I. A.
MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Supt. General of I.A.

I beg to state that the following are the respective establishments of the Methodist and Roman Catholic Churches as aided by the Department on the Caughnawaga Reserve:

Methodist.... salary of teacher.......$125.00

This is all the assistance the Department gives to the Methodist Church or any other Protestant denomination upon the Reserve. The attendance is 20 on the roll and an average attendance of 7. The school is held in a building either owned or rented by the Church authorities in which they also conduct evangelical services. Our census returns show that there are 31 Methodists upon the Reserve.

The Roman Catholics have a large stone Church and a commodious residence for the Priest, and two school buildings. The building for the boys' school is a two-story edifice of stone, and the girls' school is a frame building with school room on the first floor and rooms for the teacher on the second. The Church and the Presbytery were not erected from funds of the Dominion of Canada. The schools were built partly from Indians funds and partly from grants by the Dominion. We provide the salaries of four teachers as follows:

Boys' School, 1 teacher........... $65.00
Assistant teacher.................. $30.00
Girls' School, 1 teacher.......... $50.00
Assistant teacher.................. $50.00

The attendance of the boys' school is 126 on the roll, average 40; the girls' school, 38 on the roll and average attendance 43. There are 1,984 Roman Catholic Indians on the Reserve.

(OVER)
MEMORANDUM:

In view of the very small following the Methodist Church has upon this Reserve, I think the Department is doing all it is called upon to do by furnishing the salary of a teacher. I think that this salary should be increased to $500.00, and that beyond that amount no aid should be given.

Dr. Griffith asked for a great deal more than this, but it is not the custom of the Department to ask for an appropriation of public funds to assist any church in its missionary work. Whatever funds are provided for a church and residence must, therefore, come from the Exchequer of the Church. To my mind it is a question which should be very carefully treated; when there are so few Methodist Indians upon the Reserve, we might easily create the impression that we are endeavouring to proselytize, and it is almost certain that the impression would get abroad upon the Reserve that the Department is using not only Government funds but Indian funds for this purpose.

I would therefore beg to recommend that the salary of the school teacher be increased to $500.00, with the understanding that the teacher is to be fully qualified, and that no assistance be given to other Church work or school buildings on the Reserve.

Accountant.

Ottawa, 15th September, 1903.

With reference to the application made by Rev. Dr. Griffith of Montreal on behalf of the school conducted by the Methodist Missionary Society on the Caughnawaga Reserve, I beg to say that this Department is already paying the sum of $125.00 per annum to the Missionary Society as a contribution towards the maintenance of this school.

Two years ago when the Department took over the schools which had been carried on under the auspices of the Methodist Missionary Society in Ontario the schools in operation by the Methodists in the Province of Quebec were purposely left out of this arrangement. If the Department were called upon to pay the full salary of a teacher of the Caughnawaga Methodist school it could only do so on the understanding that it would become undenominational and I claim that there is no need for an undenominational school on this reserve as all the members of the Caughnawaga Band which numbers 2017 are all Roman Catholics, with the exception of two Anglicans and thirty-one Methodists.

There are two large Roman Catholic Schools on the reserve with two teachers for each school and it is doubtful to my mind whether the Department would be justified in maintaining a protestant school for the small number of Indian children who are not Roman Catholics.

Dr. Griffith claims that they have about thirty children.
children on the roll and that more than fifty have attended with more or less regularity. The annual report for last year shows the average attendance to have been only five, which would include nearly all the children of school age on the Reserve.

It seems to me that the Methodist Church is carrying on a school on this reserve on sufferance and I think the Department has gone as far as it would be justified in going in allowing the grant that they now receive.

I may call your attention to the fact that the Rev. Dr. Sutherland, as General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society has charge of all the Indian School work carried on by the Methodists, and any applications for increased grants should, properly speaking, come through him.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

The Rev. Mr. Timberlake, President of the Montreal Conference of the Methodist Church, has applied for the appointment of a medical officer to examine the children enrolled at the Methodist school on the Caughnawaga reserve. He says that the school has not been reopened since the summer holidays on account of the prevalence of measles, and to avoid the danger of the spread of the disease and prevent needless delay in reopening the school, he makes this application. This is the first official intimation we have had of an outbreak of measles on the reserve. The three Roman Catholic schools have opened and I can see no reason why the Methodist school should not have started at the regular time. The Methodist missionary and the teacher should have been able to find out what families, if any, are affected and order them to stay away from the school.

The children are better at school than running loose on the reserve and less liable to contract the disease. We have no regular medical officer on the reserve as the Indians generally are able to look after themselves in this respect, and I do not see why the Department should be called upon to pay for examining 35 or 30 pupils. I think Mr. Timberlake might be advised accordingly.

Dear Sir:

For some time I have been wondering what I could do for the good of the people here. At last I have thought of a plan I cannot carry out (if the people would be willing) without help from you. I will tell you my plan, then in what way I want you to help.

It is this: to organize a Girls club to meet once a week, charge a small fee for running expenses such as lighting & room, or other expenses that might arise. If any sickness I could teach them...
knitting or fancy work so far as I know myself; or we might do bead work sell it and buy materials to make some gifts for the poor children of the place to be remembered at another Christmas gathering. Once a month we could have harmless games, as young people must have amusement, and I would like to keep them away from such amusement as dancing and card parties if possible. We also could have sewing as they seem very fond of it.

Of course after talking it over with the people, new ways of working might arise but this will give you some idea of what I want to do.
Now I have no place of meeting the girls. The help I would ask you to give me would be to allow us to meet in the school-room.

Do you approve of my plan? Of course they might not come but I do want to try and do something for the Indians who once before have I tried to gather the young people together to teach them fancy work, that alone did not appeal to them, but I think the idea of the club working for the poor children of Saginawagay would inspire them to work.

One more question as I am...
writing, for a couple of years I have been wondering what literature I could get on the Indians. I also think I should tell the school children more about their own race than what comes up in their studies.

Have you a circulating library on the Indians' work or Indian people? I should say? If so, what are the conditions, and would you be willing to send the books so far away?

I wanted to write about the books before, but I know you are very busy people, and did
I don't want to trouble you too much, but I had to write you about the use of the school, as I did not feel it would be right for me to use it without first getting your permission.

If you have any suggestions to offer, they would be most gladly received.

Dear Sir:

I am glad to hear from you and I want to tell you what I have done. It has worried me so much and yet I did not see what else I could do in the face of all.

On Friday at 3 Jan. 13th I got a message from Syracuse saying my sister was dying and to come.

I did not know what to do. I wanted to see her before she died and I knew she wanted to see me, yet leaving school troubled me. Though I would
not even think of leaving without making up for lost time. Friday P.M. The agent called, I told him about the message and asked him if he thought I could go intended of course coming back on Monday. He said he did not think the Dept would mind so that I had already taught Labor Day so I felt Monday was made up anyway but even so though it would be made up, it was going away without first getting your permission that troubled me but it all happened so suddenly that I did not know what to do and if I went I must go on the evening train.
When I got there I found things in a troubled state and sister died Sunday with funeral Wednesday & Monday. Then I still intended coming Monday but my brother was so worn out and half sick himself from sitting up at night and his grief was so great he asked if I could not stay that week. I told him I had not a chance of getting permission from the Department of Indian Affairs and they would suppose I was teaching just to have them in that state seemed so hard. I tried to think of someone to take my place, and if I could get one.
I did not think you would mind quite so much.

There was a Protestant Indian here Mr. John R. Splicer who had taught in an Indian school some time before (there were no others here who had taught) and wired him to take it this week, also to wire answer. His answer was "your request is granted" and he remained until last night (Friday) So Monday there was no school, Tuesday Wednesday, Thursday and Friday Mr. Splicer taught for me.

Did I do right in this case? It troubled me so because I would never give up school for anything before unless I had
To close on account of the building being needed for the church services, for as I said I was only a servant and my duty was to do my work first. This thought was in the case of death.

What do you think about what I have done? Did I do wrong or do you think I had a right to do it in that case?

Please write me no matter what the answer may be for it has worried me so much I have often wished I had the Department near.

Sincerely,

Toronto:

Dear Mr. Shore:

Miss E. May Young, who has so satisfactorily taught our school for so many years at Caughnawaga, has been obliged to give up her school in consequence of ill health. I advised her to get a supply if possible for the last two or three weeks of the term. She tried and failed. Evidently she has tuberculosis. The Inspector visited her school early in June and told her to close the school at once. I secured for her an examination in the King Edward Institute for tuberculosis patients, and tried to get her admitted as a patient, but as she was anxious to go to her home, the doctor thought it best for her to go and so she has gone. I fear she will never return. For this I am very sorry. She loved the Indians and devoted her life to their improvement. Until two years ago she received but $250 per year, and I would be glad if I might be permitted to send to her the $40.00 for the month of June. The schools about here close on the 21st, the day before the Coronation, so that it would not be a very great act of generosity after so many years of such splendid service to pay her in full. In the city here a teacher is allowed full pay for ten days in a year if sick and half pay for forty more days. Since I have had charge of the school the last three years Miss Young has not before lost a day through sickness. I hope, therefore, I may have your consent to pay her in full. She needs and deserves it.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Wm. Timberlake.

P.S. I had sent in my schedule before I knew of Miss Young's illness and reported as paid out the full year's grant, as in the case of the other teachers.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter #152218-1, dated September 18th. I have to say that I had no knowledge whatever of Miss Stevens' appointment as teacher of the Caughnawaga Protestant school until I received the information through your letter.

In connection with the Methodist Church we have a system of organization, which includes Chairman of Districts. Rev. William Timberlake of Montreal is the Chairman of the Montreal District, which includes a considerable district outside of the city of Montreal, as well as the city itself. Mr. Timberlake is therefore in touch with the work of our Church at the Caughnawaga Reserve.

I received a letter from Mr. Timberlake on June 15th, to which I replied on the same day. I enclose herewith copies of the two letters I sent, so that you may have before you the circumstances of Miss Young's retirement from the school and the instructions which I gave to Mr. Timberlake in connection with securing applications for the school. You will note that I requested Mr. Timberlake to forward to me the correspondence which he would receive from applicants. I regret to say that I have not received any of the correspondence.

I am writing to Mr. Timberlake today, requesting a statement of the case, and drawing his attention to the procedure which I requested him to follow and also to the fact that it was not within his jurisdiction to make the appointment of the teacher. Dear Mr. Shore—

As I was out of the city during August, I asked the Rev. E. S. Morrison, who for nine years had charge of our Indian Mission at Oka, now in the city, to advertise for a teacher, stating that the salary would be $400.00. He received several applications, forwarded them to me, and I made the selection of Miss Stevens, and returned to him the correspondence in case she might need it. When your letter of the 26th ultimo came to hand, I at once wrote him for the necessary papers; and by the very same mail that these arrived I received a letter from Miss Stevens, stating that owing to letters she had received from the Department, she had closed the school and was going home. I at once wrote her, expressing my sorrow that she had so done, as there was no need for such a step, and asking her to let me know without delay if she were willing to continue the school, and it is only within the last hour that I heard from her. For some reason my letter did not reach her at the right time and she has just phoned to say she is willing to continue. She evidently misunderstood the enquiries of the Department and regarded them as undue interference, and needlessly felt insulted. Miss Stevens sent to me the last letter she received from the Department. It was very courteous, simply asking by whose authority she was teaching and stating just what you had told me, that it was the province of the Board to nominate and of the Department to affirm and appoint, also that she necessary information was probably in possession of the Board, but had not reached the Department, that when it came through the proper channel the nomination would no doubt be approved, and wishing her success in her work.

I am enclosing the application of Miss Stevens, and her credentials, also Mr. Morrison's acceptance of her application. The salary agreed upon according to advertisement was $400.00. No further agreement was signed. Miss Stevens will return to her school on Monday morning.

I am sorry for this irregularity, but as I said in my last letter, I never before heard of the Department having anything to do with the engagement of teachers, and I had overlooked the reference to it in your letter.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant in reference to the enforcement of the Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children in the village of Caughnawaga I beg to say that paragraph 1 of the Regulations provides that all Indian children between the ages of six and fifteen shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside. It rests with the parents to say whether they are to go to a Protestant or Roman Catholic school and the Department cannot interfere with their choice and paragraph 6 directs truant officers to see that children attend school regularly. In the case of parents who neglect or refuse to send their children to some school they are liable to the penalties provided for in the seventh paragraph of the Regulations.

Paragraph 14 simply defines the school to which a child shall be committed under paragraphs 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13.

March 2nd, 1917.

Dear Sir:

For some time we have had under consideration the condition of the missionary and school work at Caughnawaga. The Protestant community there is already very small, and does not seem to be growing. The position of either teacher or missionary seems scarcely adequate as an occupation for a capable person, and the expense to both the Indian Department and the Missionary Society seems considerable for the amount of service rendered. It has been proposed that we should withdraw our resident missionary and supply the work from some other point. This arrangement, however, would seem to make it impossible to secure a teacher who would live there in the absence of any other White family. In fact, we have already experienced considerable trouble in keeping a teacher at this point. Without having reached any definite conclusion, I am enquiring as to the probable attitude of the Department in case we find it possible to secure a suitable married man who would take full charge of the work as missionary-teacher. The combined expenditure would afford sufficient remuneration for the full time of a man with satisfactory qualifications in both directions.

I may say that we are now making enquiries as to
the probable fitness and availability of the present missionary, Mr. J. K. Matthews for this work. Mr. Matthews has taken a real interest in the people, and within the limits of his opportunity has been a rather successful missionary. He has, however, been carrying on this work while attending college in Montreal. He is now finishing his college course and it has been suggested to me that he might make a very desirable man for the dual position, if his services could be secured. I am putting this forward, not as a recommendation, but in order that the Department may be possessed of all the facts, and in a position to make any independent enquiry into the situation which may be deemed advisable.

On the general question of adopting the policy of a married missionary-teacher for Caughnawaga, I should be glad of an expression of opinion from the Department before taking any definite action.

Yours truly,

JHA/M.

Dear Sir:

Re Caughnawaga School -

Yours re the appointment of Miss Etta J. Smith to the Protestant School on the Caughnawaga Reserve is to hand. The explanation is as follows:

Owing to their distance from our office and certain conditions which bring their work into very close relation to that of the Church, the Missionary Society has followed the plan of having the schools at Caughnawaga and Oka looked after by the chairman of the Montreal South District of the Methodist Church. According to former practice, the former chairman has corresponded directly with the Department on a number of matters including the appointment of teachers, although of course keeping in touch with the office of the Missionary Society.

Some time before Christmas I was notified by the Rev. Robert Smith that Miss Thomson, the former teacher, was likely to leave the Caughnawaga School. Later there arrived a similar notice from the Department, accompanied by the recommendation of the inspector that the school should be closed. About the same time I received further information from the chairman of the District that Miss Etta Smith had been secured as teacher. She is not, as the name might suggest, a member of the family of the chairman, Rev. Robert Smith. Owing to our practice as reported at the beginning of this letter, I am not surprised that a teacher had been appointed without the matter being definitely submitted to me. In fact I was rather relieved to find that the work was done. It did not occur to me that the nomination had not been submitted to the Indian Department in the regular way. On thinking over the matter I find that there has been no change of teacher in this school since Rev. Mr. Smith became chairman of the Montreal South District, which accounts for the fact that he was not aware of the exact form of procedure in this matter, and so engaged Miss Smith instead of submitting her name in nomination to the Indian Department.

I am writing this explanation without an opportunity of consulting Mr. Smith but from my knowledge of the circumstances I am sure that it is the correct one. I will send a copy of this letter to him in order that my statements may be confirmed or corrected. He will also be able to furnish a statement of the qualifications of the teacher.

J. D. McLean, Esquire,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear sir: In replying to your letter Aug. 30th #551 in answer to our petition regarding the establishment of an undenominational school in Caughnawaga. Permit me to say that we consider the Indian Agent's report being most unsatisfactory, unfair, and unjust.

Unsatisfactory in that he did not consult any of the families herein mentioned as to their views on the matter. Not one single person was approached individually to ascertain their wishes. Unfair and unjust because he stated his own private opinions and based a number of his reports upon mere rumors. Furthermore we know that the agent is entirely partial to the Catholic church, and for that reason we cannot expect him to give a fair report in any matters, not pertaining to Catholicism.

Michael Skye, son of Angus Skye, and father of two (not one) children of school age, named Angus & Josephine, stated to me today that he does not intend to send his children any longer to the Catholic school.
Now re. J. Norton, we find that you representatives of the Government of Canada recognize the immature reasonings of a child rather than the legal authority of a parent who alone has absolute control over said children until they are of age. What they do after that has no bearing on the present question. Besides, the father is well known as being a strict Protestant.

Re. Thos. Patton, The agent's decision in this case is a most flagrant distortion of the truth. Because Thos. Patton has formally withdrawn his name from the Catholic Church's records and is a consistent member of the Protestant Congregation, and wishes his children to have only Protestant instruction. This is supposed to be a free country, and surely if he wishes to be a Protestant, there is no law that can force him to still remain a Catholic.

Monsieur Peter J. Montour's case, we admit that in the past they did attend the Spanish school. But we think you should recognize the fact that at the present time, Mr. Montour is sending his children to a Protestant school in Montreal, and in the event of a like school opening here, would send them to this school. May be ask what bearing any religious opinions they may have exhibited in the past has upon the question at issue? We could just as easily say, well, they are exhibiting Protestant opinions now.
In Mike Johnson's case, we notice you base your decision upon a mere rumor that one child attended Catholic services. His mother today states that this is not the case, and in any event the parents' authority should have prior recognition, rather than the probable chance going and coming of a child. The parents are the most eager and only in looking forward to a protestant school, and we might add they have three children of school age (instead of two) more, namely Victor who will be 7 yrs. old on the 8th of this Feb.

Rev. J. Phillips, the very fact that he has signed the petition is sufficient evidence to show that he wants a school established wherein his children can get protestant training. He also requested the priest to take his name away from the Catholic church records.

In Mr. Moses' case, in event a school is being established, there is no doubt but what he would arrange to have the chief board with relatives in town, so that the child would be able to regularly attend this school.

We also wish to state that a large number of families not mentioned in this petition have expressed a desire for a protestant school, and have stated that in event one opening here, they would send their children there.

Therefore we can positively state that there is a sufficient number of children ready to attend school to fulfill the requirements of the law.
Furthermore we wish to add, that the present members of the protestant congregation are going up in a body to the prairies, and request to have their names taken off their records.

So that in future the priest or agent may not be able to take advantage of this mere technicality.

In conclusion we would say we cannot accept your decision as final.

Foreseeing our petition, we request that your Department send down a representative to interview each petitioner individually.

We are ready to go to the extent of making a sworn affidavit, as to the truth every statement contained herein.

Requesting you will let us know at your earliest convenience, what is to become,

Respectfully yours,

Thos. Patton.

My dear Sir,

Please pardon the liberty I take in writing you concerning a very puzzling question, but your great kindness, your courtesy to dear Sister Mary Gabriel, former Principal, the interest you take in our work, your appreciation of the untiring efforts and the heroic patience of the Sisters, and, above all, the interest and welfare of our Indian schools, your encouraging reports, make me feel I can approach you with confidence.

Some people have been carrying a campaign of proselytizing in the village and some weak-minded Roman Catholics have abandoned the Church or are wavering. Such a course of action is very contrary to a settlement. Willing Catholic Indians may be specimens of any other faith and in the end they will turn out to be pagans. I have the deepest respect for Non-Catholics, but I have no use for those who change religion to suit their whims and their fancies. Therefore a few apostates have been sent to a Protestant school. Yesterday Mr. George, Mr. Leboeuf, Mr. Fournier, Mr. James Habourne, Mr. Montreal, came together over the duties lately performed by you; and undoubtedly he will decide whether or not the Protestant school shall be opened.

I must admit, Mr. Gilman, I do not know what to think of that movement. Why should a perfect stranger to the condition of affairs and a mentality of the flickled Indians attempt to straighten our difficulties that are revolving themselves and that were so well settled by you, January 20, 1930. Allow me to relate a sentence in your letter of the above date when you ordered the school to be closed. You said: "It was useless and a waste of funds." Can it be possible that after many years of strenuous work to train the children, to lead them to do what is good, just and honorable, we will have to turn out forty-eight little children of between six and ten years old to give room to six renegades and four Protestants? I am sure the Government does not realize what a source of trouble and disorder it may lead to. Our children, in general, inherit the warlike disposition of their fathers and always eager for a revolt; therefore, at the least little imposition of ideas they will throw to the Protestant school.

Dear Sir, I hope you will not think I have gone beyond my limits in communicating to you my feelings concerning the matter in question. I have taken my task at heart since the moment of my appointment to the office of
Principal and it is my earnest desire to work in accordance with the requests of the Government and to continue the wonderful work being done in our Schools, and I count on the support of the Officials of the Department.

At any time you or any gentlemen of the Council wish to visit us, you will be most heartily welcome.

Might I ask you to be good enough to relieve me in my anxiety as soon as possible.

With sentiments of profound respect,

I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

Sister Mary Rose (signature)

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

The Protestant Day School at Caughnawaga, which was conducted in a government-owned building, was closed in June, 1919, with the full concurrence of the Methodist Missionary Society, who were associated with us in the management. The main reason for the closing of the school was the poor attendance.

At the present time the building is used as a classroom for the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School, as all the accommodation available had to be used to care for the large enrolment.

When I visited Caughnawaga in September, last, I decided there were seven bona fide Protestant children of school age and eleven children of parents whose religion was doubtful in that they had lately broken away from the Roman Catholic Church. Our petitioners at that time were informed there were so many school causes more important than a Protestant one at Caughnawaga that favourable consideration could not be given to their request for such a school.

The Caughnawaga Village Schools are open to any Protestant children of the reserve and the Sisters have been instructed to excuse them from the study of the Roman Catholic Catechism. The bona fide Protestant children have been promised an education in Protestant residential schools, when funds can be found for the purpose and when the parents are willing to assist.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

Dear Sir:

I have taken some days to make inquiry for a suitable applicant for the Protestant School at Caughnawaga, in addition to the names you mention. I have not been successful to the present.

As one interested in the welfare of these people I am pleased to learn that the Department is devoting this attention to the reestablishing of a Protestant school on this reserve, and wish you success.

I venture to add a suggestion or so upon the situation, that has developed in Caughnawaga. As for the teacher employed: As the one responsible for the spiritual leadership of this people I hope the Dept. will see the wisdom of securing the educational leadership of a white and not an Indian. It is inevitable that we are recognizing the principle of two systems of education, as we do two systems of religion. We are forced to this conclusion, because a Protestant school cannot properly take care of itself under the leadership of an Indian with white leadership as a competitor. That is the situation that obtains at Caughnawaga. When we had the situation under our own denominational control we could safeguard this principle. Now we rely upon the Department to grant us this guardianship. In the next place, we have to recognize, that as the agitation for a Protestant school emanates from the deeper question of a religious faith, to make this a success a neutral teacher such as is always sought for by the State which is purely secular is not desirable here. This is far from being a school where religious propaganda is taught the pupils. It will give a cohesion to the work that will be the surest protection against failure in the present plans.

I have noted in your letter that none of the applicants—two Indian and one white—fully satisfied the Department. I have called upon my own responsibility of course the white applicant, Mrs. Dixon, out to my home for an exchange over the whole situation. After an exhaustive conversation I give it as my judgment that the Dept. is fortunate in securing an application for a position as unique educationally as the one at Caughnawaga.
She seems peculiarly adapted to work among the Indians. She seems to be in her element with them. She seems to make their interests hers without affectation. Her gifts and apparent qualifications are an important accomplishment in creating that moral atmosphere that counts for so much in character training. She has maturity of judgment, which ought to hold her in good stead in any delicacy of situation that might arise. And added to these is the consideration that her whole life's interest is at stake in this venture. She cannot afford to think of failure. Viewing the situation from its different sides there seems to be sufficient in her favor to justify the hope that she would wisely adapt herself to her environment. Possibly some of these suggestions may meet the fears of the Department as to her qualification.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

The attendance of the Protestant Separate School has been very good. Of the twenty enrolled, the average attendance for the first two weeks is 18.8. Those absent were kept at home on account of sickness, and three of the younger pupils did not attend one day when school was badly blocked through a heavy storm.

The general spirit of the parents, as yet, shows a fine interest in their children and loyalty to their cause; there is one exception of course, that is Mrs. Mrs. Patton whose actions have been shameful. However she is not a Protestant.

It is evident that the need of help for these pupils has been great. There is not one of the twenty who is higher than an Ontario second class. Their discipline also needs a wonderful reformation, although they seem good-hearted and anxious to learn.

This task is truly difficult but I feel certain that when the difficulties are overcome much good will be gained.

Yours respectfully,

Grace Martin

Dear Sir,

I received a letter from Mr. Bettsman, the agent, about two weeks ago, which was sent to him from the Department by Mr. McLean. This was his answer to a request I made to him to know the Municipal and Provincial holidays (of this place) mentioned in the regulations at the back of the school register, and for a school regulation, which, in other schools, is made by a school board, if I have not mistaken, and is supplementary to its regulation in the school register. I was aware that there was no board or trustees for this school but thought that there would be something provided for the teacher's benefit along this line. However, there seems nothing like that for this school, and since I know I am prepared to do the best I can without it.

In the letter I was referred to the school register for regulations, and was advised to keep the regular holidays of the village (several of which are Catholic holy days) and to consult the district supervisor on the matter. I did this and it was agreed that this school being Protestant could keep the holidays, in other Protestant schools of the Province and would not offend by so doing. This was a great relief to me as it prevented possible trouble.

The work has exactly described when said to be "very difficult," but there is much to be thankful for too. Although difficulties have been met with, no
have been escaped. There may be trouble with Mrs. Thomas, also. Her husband is away at work and she has charge of the children. I have had to be very patient with her. I do not wish to be harsh but may be compelled to use authority for the sake of the school. There is one thing I do wish to know—If at any time I am unjustly accused of doing wrong, and the accusation disproved by false witness, have I any protection? Since I have realized how very difficult and dangerous this position is, I would have been glad to leave, as soon as possible. This is just one thing that has made it possible for me to face it, and that is, the great need of help, of these people, who are my fellow sufferers, but it is wholly self-sacrifice. I am ready for troubles but would like to have some assurance of safety. I have gone to the sisters according to your advice, but from my reception, I felt that I was intruding. If it is not absolutely necessary that I be sent to them again, could you kindly excuse me from that, for a while at least? I expect better things in the future, but I do believe that a spirit of cooperation must have time to grow.

Yours respectfully,

Grace Martin

P.S. I believe I reported to you before the low standard of efficiency of the pupils of this school which you will see by the quarterly report. This has only made the work harder than an ordinary school instead of being easy as it may appear, as junior classes need so much individual attention. I have been accustomed to spending a great deal of my class work time on the junior pupils and diminishing them at the expense of the seniors and with the Indians' consent I continued the practice but he seems to have changed his mind and wishes me to take care of the seniors and to help myself with the juniors.

Dear Sir:

I was very shocked to see a letter addressed to Mr. Agent Létourneau following a complaint that I have been calling school at irregular hours. I wish to deny this charge as I ring the bell to call the children in promptly at 9:00 AM and 1:30 PM by my watch. We have no clock at the school but I have been getting the time over the radio and it does not vary more than two or three minutes from the bell at the Catholic Church.

I have interviewed the Sister Superior and Constable Jocks and neither has heard any complaint of this nature against me. The Sister Superior can hear my bell every time it rings.
I am very sorry that this has occurred as this is the first time, during the time I have been teaching, that I have been charged with breaking school laws. I like my work and it is not my intention to shirk it at any time.

There were a few times during the very cold weather when I could not call school at nine o'clock as the room was much too cold. Probably these are the times that were referred to.

Dear Sir:

In view of the following facts -

1. That our protestant school enrollment has outgrown its present accommodation and is still growing.

2. That no adequate playground is provided the children under conditions, with the result that they are compelled to play on the public highway with resultant danger to life and limb.

3. That we were definitely assured by Mr. Ferrier when the Protestant school was re-opened that the other school which was formerly the Methodist Mission school would be returned to us.

4. That the present building is wholly unsuited for a school building such as is outlined in the regulations regarding such buildings, because -

   (a) It is unsanitary and unsatisfactory

   (b) It is badly ventilated and the lighting system is poor, with a dark gloomy interior.

   (c) It is draughty and cold in winter and lacks proper blackboard space.

5. That our Band Council and other public spirited men are wholly in sympathy with our demands.

6. That this school was started as an experiment and we believe the experiment has proven successful.

7. That in Miss Green we have found a capable and efficient teacher, but who cannot render the best service under the present conditions and without the assistance among so many children.

We the undersigned submit these facts believing that the Indian Affairs Department would remedy these conditions, were they acquainted with the situation.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. McGILL,

As the United Church has now placed a missionary on the Caughnawaga Reserve, their missionary's residence, which has been used as the junior room of the Caughnawaga United Church school, will not be available for the coming academic year.

Agent Brisebois and Rev. Mr. Dean visited several houses in Caughnawaga but could not find a place suitable for the school. The Sister Superior of the Caughnawaga R. C. School kindly offered to allow a room in the Eastern School for the junior room of the United Church School.

Apparently, this arrangement did not suit the United Church authorities, as Reverend Dr. William Munroe, head of the United Church mission work in the Montreal district, visited the Department last week and requested that an official of the Department come to the Reserve and meet the United Church authorities.

With the approval of Mr. Williams, I went to Caughnawaga on the 10th instant, and Rev. Dr. William Munroe, Rev. A. McTaggart and Mr. Guy Tombs came to Mr. Brisebois' office at 10 o'clock that morning.

We discussed the matter carefully and visited - the Eastern
the Eastern School, where it was proposed to have the room, but finally the United Church officers requested that they be allowed to conduct the junior room in their church.

While this will be a considerable inconvenience to them, I could see no objection on the part of the Department, and I therefore informed them that I would recommend this arrangement to you for the academic year 1936-37. Mr. Brisebois can arrange to have the desks moved into the church without cost.

The United Church authorities consider that the Department should either enlarge the present United Church school, to provide another classroom, or erect a separate building. In this regard Rev. Mr. A. McTaggart intends to interview you some time next month and request that funds for the above purpose be provided in our Appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38.

Sir:

May I be permitted to bring to your attention a very serious matter which concerns the welfare of five Indian children who have been expelled from school at Caughnawaga, P.Q.

For your information, I am a minister of the Gospel, also a travelling representative of the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society, and am authorized to counsel and advise those who are Jehovah's Witnesses, therefore it comes inside my province to act on behalf of these children and accordingly I bring the following facts to your attention:

Five children were expelled on April 11, 1940 from the United Church Indian Day School for not saluting the flag. The children involved are:

Joyce Williams, 12 years
Myrna Williams, 11 "
Elmer Horne, 13 "
Orval Williams, 9 "
Peter Williams, 6 "

All these children are resident on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve. The only reason for the expulsion of these children is that of not saluting the flag. I understand that the children's teacher, Miss Nesbitt, reported the refusal of these children to salute the flag to the Indian Agent, Mr. Brisbois, who reported the matter to Ottawa. The Department of Indian Affairs instructed that the children be suspended. The teachers, Miss Nesbitt and Miss Bryan were interviewed and have had the situation explained to them, and it has also been explained to Mr. Brisbois.

Our local representative at Ottawa, Mr. Chas. Morrell, has taken up this matter with Mr. Phelan, of the Department of Indian Affairs, in an effort to explain the action and attitude of the
children, but he was treated discourteously in not being permitted to have any kind of hearing by the Department concerned.

Therefore on behalf of these children and their parents, and in the interests of liberty and justice, I am appealing this decision to you. I trust you will give this very serious case your personal attention, and that you will see your way clear to remedy this great injustice which has been meted out to these children.

That you may be in a position to appreciate the reason for the children's stand, I suggest the following to you:

That the children's loyalty is not at all in question. It is merely the manner of expressing it.

That in their belief the mode of expressing it is repugnant to the law of Almighty God and hence to the children's freedom of conscience and freedom of worship. They sincerely believe it to be a violation of the law of Almighty God. Should it not have been allowed that the children should have been given a hearing before being expelled?

That it is correct for each one to worship the Lord according to the dictates of his own conscience provided that in so doing they do not violate good morals, infringe on other's rights or jeopardize the safety of the State.

That each person should be allowed to decide for himself whether his belief is right or wrong.

I also suggest that if this condition regarding these children remains unaltered they will be deprived of their education and such being the case, then surely such teacher should cease teaching that there is freedom of conscience and freedom of worship.

This matter should now be faced fairly and honestly. Should the teacher, or those higher in authority, be permitted to
make hypocrites of children of the land? Or shall the parents be denied the liberty to teach them the Word of God?

Can you properly take away the right of private judgment of school children or parents? Can you rightfully deny school attendance to a child who without injuring anyone puts allegiance to His God ahead of school regulations?

I further suggest that no one will be harmed by the children being permitted to attend school and stand mute while others salute. In such a case the result is that the right of the children to adhere to their conscience is upheld. No one is hurt and the country is not endangered.

I trust that this entire matter will receive your earnest, unbiased, courageous consideration and that your decision will be in accord with the true worship of Almighty God and with the principles held dear to democracy.

Yours very truly,

Charles F. Royton
Ottawa, May 4, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 29, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, the claim of a group of pupils for re-admission to one of the Indian day schools on the Caughnawaga reserve, P. Q.

The records here indicate that the Indian agent in charge of the Caughnawaga reserve reported to the Department on April 2, 1940, that a group of students attending the Indian day school, operated under the auspices of the United Church, had been causing trouble at that school by refusing to join with others in the singing of The National Anthem and by refusing to salute the flag. The agent, in a letter sent to him from the Department, dated April 8, 1940, was instructed to advise the teachers in charge of that particular school that any pupil who refused to recognize constituted authority and who disobeyed reasonable orders should be immediately discharged from the school.

You can readily realize how necessary it is to have strict regulations governing the conduct of pupils attending Indian day and residential schools throughout the Dominion. You will fully appreciate, also, that it would be utterly impossible to conduct schools at all if every religious denomination or sect insisted upon regulations in conformity with their own religious tenets and beliefs. Such insistence would simply lead to confusion and chaos. The aim in a democratic country such as Canada is to carry out a policy acceptable

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL

I am attaching hereto copy of a letter received by this Branch from Reverend Robert B. Cochrane, D.D., Secretary of the Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada.

You will note that Dr. Cochrane submits for departmental consideration copy of a resolution passed by the Montreal Presbytery of the United Church at their meeting held on Tuesday May 7, 1940.

It would appear that Indian Agent Brisebois reported to the Department on April 8, 1940, that a group of pupils attending the Indian day school operated under the auspices of the United Church on the Caughnawaga reserve had been causing trouble at the school by refusing to join with others in the singing of the National Anthem and by refusing to salute the flag. The Agent in a letter sent forward to him from the Department dated April 8, 1940, was instructed to advise the teachers in charge of that particular school that any pupil who refused to recognize constituted authority and who disobeyed reasonable orders should be immediately discharged from the school. It is my understanding that since these instructions were issued two pupils have been discharged from the school.

In my monthly report for April I referred to my visit to the Caughnawaga reserve and to the urgent need for greater police patrol work and protection at Caughnawaga. I am still of the opinion that in times as serious as the times in which we are now living an R. C. M. P. officer should be permanently located on this reserve. If, however, funds are not available to adopt this recommendation, I would recommend that the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police be asked to make a quiet investigation, preferably by a plain clothes detective, of conditions at the United Church school, the distribution referred to in the resolution sent forward by Dr. Cochrane and the activities of the Indian Chief at Caughnawaga, as well as a number of other matters that may be brought to his attention by the Indian Agent.

Dear Miss Joblin:

In reporting on his recent visit to your school Mr. Doucet intimates that he stressed the practical side of education rather than the strictly academic phase. You are probably aware that Mr. Doucet has had very wide experience as an instructor both in vocational and academic subjects and was, prior to his appointment to this Department, an instructor at the vocational school in Regina.

The Department's aim is to prepare the pupils to cope with the exigencies of life as they are found in the community in which they reside. The school programme, we believe, should begin with social settings that surround the community. Education is really an affair of action and not simply an affair of acquiring ready-made responses through mechanical repetition. We incline to that process of education by means of which meaningful experiences prepare for life.

As a result we are anxious to have manual training wherever possible. We are certain that you will do your best to introduce and encourage this phase of educational effort in your school.

I realize that carrying out our wishes will necessarily involve a considerable departure from the provincial curriculum but our experience in Indian work has proved to our satisfaction that the policy we now suggest is best suited to Indian children.

Yours truly,

I wish to inform you that Miss Doris K. Diabo who taught at the third class of the United Indian Village Day School during September last, has discontinued teaching on the 30th ultimo. She worked for the whole month of September.

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Caughnawaga (United Church) Indian Day School, No. 30h.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th of October last, enclosing the original of a letter received at the Branch from one Peter Diome, an indian of this Reserve, who was requesting the Branch to pay for the transportation of his children from his place of residence near the St.Isidore Rd., School, to the local U.C., Indian Day School, located in this Village, four miles from his home.

In reply I wish to say that Peter who was living in the Village, up to last summer, had in the course of the winter requested to have his children transferred from the R.C.School to the U.C.School. His reason was that he had left the R.C.Church to join the Long House or had became an aboriginal believer.

At the time he made his application, same was refused because children are not allowed to change from one School to another in the middle of the academic year. When a child start going to school in September at a certain place he has to finish the school year at that same place. This ruling has been established for obvious reasons.

This last September, Diome and his family had moved to a farm on the St.Isidore road and he sent his children to the Village U.C.School instead of sending them to the St.Isidore Rd.,School (half a mile from his home) and consequently applied for their transportation to be paid because we do pay the transportation of children living in the area of the Bush Rd.,School, which was closed last year because of the limited number of pupils and also for lack of a teacher. Peter claims that his case is the same and that if we pay for some we should pay for everyone regardless of the circumstances.

The fact....
The fact that he has changed his religious beliefs is considered as being strictly his own business but in this case it is wondered if it would be fair for the Branch to pay for the transportation of these children to attend a certain school when they have one located close by.

May I say that the hiring of a taxi would entail an expense of at least $2.00 a day and when the road closes for the winter the hiring of a man with a horse or horses will amount to not less than $4.00 per day. No children of that vicinity are coming to the Village Schools. Diome's letter is herewith returned.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 28, 1947.

Dear Mrs. Ross:

I have for answer your letter as received today.

Unfortunately, the school at Kettle Point has been filled for some time now. However, we have another classroom vacancy at Moraviantown (a few miles from Highgate, Ontario). This is a new classroom which is being opened in the Indian council hall directly adjacent to our present one-room day school. There would be some 25 children in the primary grades. This classroom would be ready for occupation immediately after the Christmas holidays.

We also have a vacancy in the province of Quebec, at the Caughnawaga United Church Day School. This also is a primary room and is located near the village of Lachine opposite Montreal. In both instances the salary would be the same, namely $1,500.00 per academic year. At Caughnawaga we have a rented house in which the other two lady teachers stay. There is a room for a third teacher there and, in fact, it is now being so occupied. The teacher at present in this position is in ill health and wishes to either retire or move to one of our schools in Manitoba. This position would also be open as of the first of January.

I am returning your letter, as requested.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard P. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mrs. Ross:

I have for answer your letter of December 8. It is noted that you would prefer the primary room at the Caughnawaga School rather than the vacancy at Moraviantown.

Miss Daly, the Principal of this school, was in Ottawa last week end and I discussed the situation with her. They have a substitute teacher in the primary room until the Christmas holidays.

Dear Mrs. Trenholm:
