Announcement of the Summer School for Teachers
Macdonald College, 1949.

The eighteenth annual summer school for teachers, under the auspices of the Department of Education, will be held at Macdonald College from Monday, July 4, to Saturday, July 30, inclusive. This summer school is intended for teachers holding elementary and intermediate certificates or diplomas valid in the Province of Quebec.

The purpose of this summer school is to enable certificated teachers to supplement their previous training, to become better acquainted with modern educational movements and methods, and to qualify for more advanced diplomas, in accordance with the regulations of the Protestant Committee of the Council of Education.

Elementary and intermediate certificates shall remain interim until the holder thereof shall have taught for two years successfully and shall also have successfully completed one summer session at an approved professional summer school, when the interim certificate shall be exchanged for a permanent diploma.

Advanced elementary diplomas shall be issued to holders of permanent elementary diplomas who have taught successfully for at least two years and have successfully completed three sessions at an approved summer school, one of which must be professional in character.

Intermediate certificates or diplomas shall be granted to teachers holding elementary certificates or diplomas, provided they have obtained the senior high school leaving certificate. The senior high school leaving examination may be taken in two sections for this purpose.
Advanced intermediate diplomas shall be issued to holders of permanent intermediate diplomas who shall have taught successfully for two years and completed satisfactorily three sessions, one of which must be a professional summer school, at one or more approved summer schools.

Teachers whose certificates have lapsed are eligible for attendance at summer school only after receiving special permission from the Director of Protestant Education.

Applicants will be admitted who for some sufficient reason are unable to take the whole course in one year but could take one complete course in two sessions of the summer school. No credit or bonus can, however, be given unless a complete summer school requirement is fulfilled. Applications for admission will be considered from students who wish to take partial courses without regard to credits or bonus.

Each application must be accompanied by a preliminary deposit of $10. Money orders or cheques for this amount, with the bank charge included, must be drawn in favour of the Secretary, Macdonald College.

Candidates will be admitted, subject to available accommodation, in the order of the receipt of their applications, preference being given, if possible, to students who have attended previous summer sessions.

All applications must be made on or before June 18, 1949.

Students who apply for and receive admission certificates, but who for good and sufficient reasons find themselves unable to attend the summer school, may ask for and obtain a refund of their preliminary deposit at any time up to June 18, 1949. This date for withdrawal is necessary in order to allow vacant accommodation to be made available for other applicants.

The total living expenses from noon, July 4, to noon, July 30, will be $38 for board and room (two in a room) including registration and medical fees. Those desiring a single room may obtain one, if available, at a small extra cost, by writing in advance to the Secretary, Macdonald College. The preliminary deposit is accepted as part of the total charge. The balance only is required to be paid on the first day of the session. All bed linen, towels, etc. will be supplied by the College. Personal laundry work will be done by the College laundry at a reasonable charge.

Arrangements have been made whereby Dr. R. F. Kelso or his locum tenens will attend the College daily to give medical attention to students who may require professional service. The medical fee will cover the charges of ordinary sickness while at the College but not of infectious diseases or major operations.

Students will be expected to provide themselves in advance with the books and materials required in the different courses in accordance with the subjects chosen.

General Information

Students should arrive, if possible, during the forenoon of Monday, July 4, for registration between 9 A.M. and noon. Immediately upon arrival students should present their certificates of admission at the Secretary's office, Room 11, Main Building, for the purpose of completing payment for living expenses. Only after this has been done will rooms be assigned in the residence.

All classes will open at 1.30 P.M. in the College Assembly Hall on Monday, July 4.

A certificate of attendance will be sent each year to successful students.

Again this year the Railways and Steamship Lines, members of the Canadian Passenger Association, are putting into effect for Summer Schools special reduced fares on Certificate Plan, i.e. one-way fare and one-half for round trip for teachers, pupils and dependent members of their families when accompanying them, travelling from stations in Canada east of and including Armstrong and Fort William.

In order to take advantage of this reduction, it will be necessary for each passenger to purchase a one-way ticket at full fare from his home station to Ste. Anne de Bellevue, Quebec, obtaining then from the ticket agent a "Standard Convention Certificate"; the
going journey must commence between June 30 and July 6, both dates inclusive. Upon surrender of the certificate, properly signed by the authorized officer of the summer school, to the ticket agent at Ste. Anne de Bellevue, Que., not later than August 3, 1949, a ticket for the return journey may be purchased at one-half of the regular one-way fare; it will be valid until August 29, 1949, and will permit of stop-overs.

Courses offered

In planning their work students attending the Summer School for the first time should arrange to take at least one of the professional subjects that are offered and, avoiding undue concentration in familiar fields, should choose such other courses as will help to broaden their cultural horizons. Those, however, who are working for advanced diplomas may find some degree of specialization advisable. The combination of courses to be taken by any student must be approved by the Director of the Summer School.

Art and Crafts:

Course I — Elementary Work One Unit

1. Making a pictorial alphabet.
2. Pattern making for the junior grades:
   (a) The use of cut or torn paper.
   (b) Constructional elements in design.
3. Object drawing in light and shade.
4. Practical application of colour to craftwork.
5. Bookcraft:
   (a) A snap-shot album.
   (b) A single-section stitched book.
6. Potato-block cutting and printing in one, two and three colours.
7. Landscape posters in cut paper and paint.

Necessary materials will be provided at cost price.

All students are required to bring paints and brushes, pencil, ruler, compasses, eraser, a knife, a clean rag or duster, and a reasonably large pair of scissors. An ordinary kitchen paring knife is excellent for potato-block cutting and is comparatively safe for children.

The necessary tools for bookcraft will be furnished by the Instructor.

Mr. C. V. Frayn.

Course II — Advanced Work One Unit

1. Plant and flower drawing for design:
   (a) The plant.
   (b) Its characteristic growth.
   (c) Its adaptation to design.
2. Watercolour techniques:
   (a) Using various types of paper.
   (b) Using body colour.
3. Historical figure drawing for imaginative work.
4. Bookcraft:
   (a) Making a note case.
   (b) Rebinding a paper-backed book in half or whole cloth.
5. Gesso craft:
   (a) Preparing the design in conjunction with No. 1 above.
   (b) Applying the design.
6. Leatherwork for beginners.

Necessary materials will be provided at cost price.

All students must bring scissors, paints and brushes, pencil, ruler, compasses and eraser. A clean rag or duster will also be required.

The necessary tools for leatherwork and bookcraft will be provided.

Mr. C. V. Frayn.
Bible Study:

Course I — The Bible as Literature One Unit

Backgrounds of the Bible: a study of the origins of the Bible, its literature, meaning and place in the life of man.

The course will include an account of how we got our Bible, particularly how we obtained the various versions. There will be an exposition of its contents — folklore, history, poetry, wisdom literature, letters and prophecy — as well as an interpretation of the purpose of the Bible and its decisive influence upon the history of man.

Rev. G. G. D. Kilpatrick, D.D.

Course II — The Bible in Grades V and VIII One Unit

Teaching values in the Scripture assignments for Grades V and VIII.

The course will consist of an exposition of the literary, moral and religious values in the passages prescribed for Grades V and VIII.

Rev. G. G. D. Kilpatrick, D.D.

Education:

Course I — Child Development and Guidance One Unit

Types of guidance by specialists and regular teachers. Adjustment to school and life. The child's innate urges and drives, interests, abilities, aptitudes, and social and economic needs. Potentialities and limitations. Psychological insight: discovery of symptoms of maladjustment and treatment. Study of individual differences, methods of assignments, methods of study and learning. Health; social, civic, moral, emotional, educational, and vocational adjustments. Individual conferences: guidance in elementary and rural schools; home and school relationships.

Texts: (1) Helping Teachers Understand Children, American Council on Education, Washington, D.C.

(2) Child Development and Guidance in Rural Schools by Strang and Hatcher, Harper.

Dr. Sinclair Laird.

Course II — Activities One Unit

Project, enterprise and activity methods in individual subjects and groups of subjects; correlation and coordination. The principle of learning by doing. Philosophical, psychological and social principles involved. Necessary adjustments in aims, methods, discipline, materials and timetable. Extra-curricular activities to supplement school methods for purposes of child development. Suitable activities for varieties of school conditions and environments.

Text: Activities in the Elementary School by McKown, McGraw-Hill.

Dr. Sinclair Laird.

English:

Course I — Shakespeare One Unit

Lectures will be given on some important aspects of Shakespeare's philosophical background, illustrated from a variety of plays. A more detailed study will be made of Hamlet. Students should provide themselves with a complete Shakespeare (any edition).

Dr. G. I. Duthie.

Course II — English Literature of the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Centuries One Unit

The course will consist of a survey of the most important poets and prose writers of the period. The background will be sketched. The writers' biographies will be recounted, and their principal works will be critically analysed. Their thought will be expounded, and their literary achievements will be assessed. The aim of the course will be to ensure that teachers, in giving more elementary instruction to their pupils in the schools, will be able themselves to rely on a true understanding of the period and the individual writers.

Dr. G. I. Duthie.
French:

Course I — Practical French Conversation One Unit

The class will be divided into small groups, in accordance with their proficiency, to permit more individual practice. These groups will discuss definite weekly topics, such as the following: the school, the home, public services, common business terms, social life.

Word lists to aid in preparing and discussing these topics will be mimeographed and furnished to the students.

For this course students should provide themselves with a French dictionary and a copy of Avantages.

Mr. G. H. King.

Course II — French Grammar and Syntax One Unit

Fundamentals of French grammar, including syntax and common idioms.

This course will attempt to diagnose and correct the more common errors made by English-speaking students of French, thus aiding them to improve their accuracy in speaking and writing the language.

No textbooks will be required for this course, but mimeographed material may be supplied to the students.

Mr. G. H. King.

Geography:

Course I — North America in the Modern World One Unit

Canada, with her new province of Newfoundland, and the United States. Studies of representative Indian tribes and their adaptation to their environment.

Practical work: lantern-slide making, model making and poster designing.

Sources of illustrative material and a method of duplicating.

Methods of presenting geographical principles.

Text: Canada and Her Neighbours by Taylor, Seiveright and Lloyd, Ginn & Co.

Miss Marian B. Banks.

Course II — World Geography One Unit

History of the modern map and map projections.

Race.

Special emphasis will be devoted to the following countries: India and Pakistan, China, Israel and the U.S.S.R.

Practical work: lantern-slide making, map reading — weather and topographical.

Sources of illustrative material and a method of duplicating.

Text: World Geography by Bradley, Ginn & Co.

A mimeographed outline of the lectures to be given in the two Geography courses will be obtainable.

Miss Marian B. Banks.

Mathematics:

Course I One Unit

Teaching Arithmetic in Grades III, IV and V, with special reference to modern classroom textbooks.

The use of devices, recreational activities, concrete materials and films will be studied.

Arithmetic readiness, individual differences, achievement and diagnostic tests, the place of mental arithmetic, and many other topics will be included in this course.
Students are advised to bring with them copies of the authorized texts.

For class reference: *How to Make Arithmetic Meaningful* by L. J. Brueckner and F. E. Grossnickle, the John C. Winston Co., 1947.

Professor William A. Steeves.

**Course II**

One Unit

Teaching Arithmetic in Grades VI, VII, VIII and IX, with special reference to modern classroom textbooks.

This course will include a study of the child's progress, diagnostic techniques, remedial teaching, the use of classroom films, mental arithmetic, and many other aspects of the teaching of Arithmetic.

Students are advised to bring with them copies of the authorized texts.

For class reference: *Elementary Arithmetic — Its Meaning and Practice* by B. R. Buckingham, Ginn and Company, 1947.

*Remedial Techniques in Basic School Subjects* by G. M. Fernald, McGraw-Hill.

Professor William A. Steeves.

**Music:**

**Course I — The New Course in Listening**

One Unit

A practical lecture course for the urban or rural school teacher.

1. A detailed analysis of recordings included in the course of study in Music for Grades I - VII.
2. How to prepare and present a 'listening lesson'.
3. Background lectures on composers, periods in music, terminology, form and other miscellaneous points.

4. The child's response to music.
5. Activities as part of the listening programme.

Text: *Let's Listen to Music* by Clarkson, Gordon V. Thompson Ltd.

Professor Frank Hanson.

**Course II — Methods and Materials**

One Unit

Based on the new course of study in Music for Grades I - VII and organized on the plan of a workshop, the course will give the individual teacher an opportunity to fulfill immediate grade music needs. In addition, the following activities are planned for the entire group:

1. Voice development and the presentation of songs.
2. Conducting techniques.
3. The development of music reading skills.
4. Choirs and festivals.

Texts: *Course of Study in Music for Elementary Schools*, Department of Education, Quebec.

Song and sight reading books of the *High Road of Song* series by Dann, W. J. Gage & Co., for the grade or grades which the teacher wishes to cover during the course.

Professor Frank Hanson.

**Primary Methods:**

**Course I — Arithmetic in Grades I and II**

One Unit

This course will deal with the requirements of the Grade I Arithmetic course as outlined in the 1948 *Supplement to the Handbook for Teachers* and will detail a developmental series of teaching procedures for the systematic presentation of the number processes at the Grade II level.
Students enrolled in the course will be required to make individual and classroom teaching materials. For this purpose students should bring India ink, paste, lettering-pens and paint brushes. Pictures clipped from magazines will also be required for the pictorial representation of number groupings.

Miss Blanche Stewart.

Course II — Spelling in the Language Arts One Unit Programme

This course is intended for teachers of the second and third grades. Students will be required to prepare weekly word-study exercises for children to cover the year's spelling course, which will correlate with the reading and language programme in the development of skills in phonetic and structural analysis.

Students planning to take this course should bring the Quance Speller for Grades II and III and the Curriculum Foundation Readers and Guidebooks for either Grade II or Grade III.

Dear Mr. Hierlihy:

You will recall our previous correspondence concerning a position in one of our Indian day schools. I have just returned from an inspection trip to the Caughnawaga Reserve at Lachine, P.Q., and am writing to you immediately upon my return to Ottawa.

I am pleased to be able to offer you the position of principal of the Caughnawaga United Church Indian Day School at a commencing salary of $1,920.00 an academic year. We have a revised salary schedule in course of preparation now and your salary may actually be higher than this if the scale is approved by 1 September, 1949.

You would be responsible for the teaching of the upper grades, namely 7, 8 and 9, and would have two other teachers under you for the intermediate and primary grades.

In addition to this salary, we will provide a furnished teacher's apartment. I do not believe that I have raised the question of whether you are married and have any family. In any event, there would be accommodation for both your wife and yourself and family. If you are not married, then I believe we can arrange for another male teacher to share the apartment with you. Our appointments are of a continuous type and are not renewed annually.

If it is at all possible for you to accept this position, I would be glad to provide you with any further details. In conclusion may I point out that this school is 30 minutes by
bus from the centre of Montreal and that you will be able to take university courses at McGill without any inconvenience as the bus service is half-hourly.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Since the enclosed Monthly Report of Attendance for October was returned to me for correction due to the fact that I accidently counted two white children who are attending this school, I decided that this would be an opportune time to enquire about the status of these white children in this school.

At the same time as I received the incorrect report, I received the new school requisition forms for supplies. At the top of these forms it says: "These supplies are for Indian children only". The white children, who are attending this school, are evidently allowed to do so because their parents lease farms on the reserve, and are supposed to farm. But I do not see why they should be given free supplies.

Some time ago Miss Burden, the junior teacher, was short of Pre-primers. Knowing that the white children were not supposed to be furnished books, I told her to write to the parents of one of the white pupils in her room and ask them to buy a Pre-primer for him. The following is a copy of the note which Miss Burden received from the parent:

"When we rented this farm, we were told by the Indian Agent, that white children could go to the Indian school, with free transportation and school supplies as the Indian children. So we do not see why we should buy books for Frankie, when we never did for the other two children."

Yours truly,

(Signed) William J. Skinner.

If we have to supply these white children and others with texts and other supplies then we will have to requisition for supplies counting them in, even though the "supplies as for Indian children only".

I would also like to enquire if anything is going to be done about getting better transportation for the children who are being transported to school? It is nearly five o'clock every night before the last of these children leave the school. At the request of some of the parents, and also out of charity, we have been keeping the children, who go by bus, in the school until the bus arrives. This necessitates one of the staff staying each night till five o'clock to supervise. Since the cold weather began, I have also been allowing the children from the R.C. Day School, who wish, to come into our school to wait for the bus. It is far too cold for them to stand out on the road for an hour waiting for the bus.

I have talked with Father Bechard, Principal of the R.C. Day School about this matter and he is of the same mind as I about the
We both think that it is criminal to have the children walking around until such a late hour. They do not get home until five-thirty or later, and this is far too long a day for any child.

There is one other thing that I would like to ask about. I spoke to both Mr. Brisebois and Mr. Doucet about this matter: Viz., the question of supplying a hot drink of hot soup for the children who must bring their lunch to school on account of the distance they live from school. As you know, a hot lunch was provided at Shawenaga after I requested Mr. Devlin to ask the department for it. I think that the children here, who have to bring their lunch should also be provided with a hot cup of cocoa or a cup of soup. Even though some of them can afford to buy milk or soft drinks every day, there are others who can't.

The two female members of my staff both stay to supervise during noon hour anyway, and they would be willing to look after the making of the soup if the Department will be good enough to supply it.

If the Department would consider providing soup for the 30 children who regularly bring their lunch, we would need the following amount of soup and also these supplies:

**Soup Five Days a Week for January, February & March for 30 Pupils**

Soup—6 cases of 48 cans each—Aylmer or Campbell's or Heinz Soup which can be diluted—Vegetable, Veg.—Beef, and Tomato

1 Hot-plate—on which to heat the soup

1 large aluminum preserving kettle and cover

30 white enamel cups

30 teaspoons

1 large soup ladle

2 sets of large salt & pepper shakers

1 can opener

1 dishpan

6 tea towels

Soap flakes or bar soap

An answer as to your decision on the above three matters will be greatly appreciated, at your earliest convenience.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal,
Caughnawaga U.C. Day School.

Mitchel L. Deere:
Ottawa, Dec. 27, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of recent date, relative to the repairs and replacements on the Methodist Church at Caughnawaga, in which building it is proposed to conduct a separate school. As you were informed by the Superintendent of Indian Education, the Department desires to give this school activity a fair trial; but we do not wish to incur heavy capital expense until the success of the undertaking has been assured. Mr. Ferrier promised that the building would be floored and that a Quebec heater would be installed. No other expense, that is not absolutely necessary, can be undertaken at this time. Desks, a blackboard and other classroom equipment will, of course, be supplied.

You should write to the Department, formally offering the church for school purposes on these conditions. The Indian agent will be asked to report on the need for outdoor closets and certain other repairs that are mentioned in your communication, but the Department cannot undertake to expend a large sum from Parliamentary Appropriation, on a building that it does not own, before a separate school has been given a fair trial.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Mr. Mitchel Lt. Deere,

Ottawa, Dec. 27, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has decided to give a fair trial to a Protestant school at Caughnawaga. Four years ago, with the concurrence of your office, this activity was discontinued because of poor attendance. There are at present a few bona fide Protestant children of school age and certain other children, whose parents have stated that they are now Protestants and would like a separate school. Mr. Mitchel Deere, the lay preacher, has offered the Methodist Church building for school purposes and my object in writing to you is to have you confirm this offer. The Department intends to put in a new floor, properly heat the building and equip it with the necessary classroom furniture.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, January 9, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the repairs and equipment required to fit up the mission building to be used as a classroom in connection with the Protestant day school which it is proposed to re-open on the Chuksnaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that authority has already been granted you to purchase the maple flooring required, also the Quebec heater and the necessary stove pipe.

You may arrange for the installation of the 4 double windows required, and you may also arrange to have the inside walls burlapped to a height of about 5', and given two coats of paint.

Regarding the erection of an outside coal bin and closets, it is considered that a building having a compartment of sufficient size in the centre for the coal and wood and a closet at each end—one for boys and one for girls—would be the best arrangement. You may, therefore, arrange to have a building of the required size erected. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and you should purchase all materials required after competitive prices have been obtained. Padlocks should be installed on the door of each closet and on the door of the fuel compartment. The Department will leave the erection of this building in your hands, to see that satisfactory and ample provision is made for closets for both the boys and girls and for the storage of the fuel. You may also arrange to purchase the quantity of wood and coal required for the balance of the present winter, and competitive prices should be obtained, if possible.

I have to request that you will state as soon as possible the dimensions of the blackboards required. You should measure the wall space on which it is proposed to place the boards, and state the length and width required. As soon as this information is received, an order will be placed here for the blackboards required.

As you have been informed in a separate communication, the Department is placing an order for the school desks and other furnishings required. A supply of books, stationery, etc., will be forwarded from the Government Stationery Office.

The labour required should be performed by members of the Band, under the charge of Mitchell Deer as foreman. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed.

When the above work has been completed, you should forward

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.
properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material purchased, together with a memo showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted, as well as time sheets, in duplicate, for the labour, properly certified.

You will be good enough to attend to the repairs required in order to have the building ready for classroom purposes as soon as possible. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and the Department will expect you to see that the work is performed and the material supplied as cheaply as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, I beg to inform you that the dimensions of the two blackboards required for the use of the Protestant School at Caughnawaga, would be 8 feet long for each and a height of about 3 feet. I intend to have these blackboards placed one at each end of the classroom.

It is suggested by the man in charge of the alterations to be made at the mission building, (an Indian named Mitchell Deere) that a door be placed near one of the corners at the rear of the classroom, in order to facilitate the exit of the pupils and the getting in of the wood and coal from the proposed building that is to be put up towards the rear of the school lot. I believe that this idea is recommendable, and if approved by your Department I beg to ask your authorization to purchase the necessary material. In case of this new opening at the rear of the building, it would be necessary, as stated above, to have one of the blackboards placed at each end of the classroom, otherwise, it would be preferable to have them both placed in front of the pupils, but, at one end or the other the dimensions are the same as stated above. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, and in reply beg to inform you that an order is today being placed with the Government Stationery Office to forward addressed to you at Adirondack Junction, Que., 2 beaver plate blackboards, each 8' x 3' wide, with the necessary chalk trough and moulding, for the use of the Protestant school on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

The Department is not prepared to authorize the placing of a door in one of the corners at the rear of the classroom. It is considered that by so doing it would interfere with the placing of blackboards in their proper positions in the classroom. It would be unsatisfactory to have one of these boards placed at the rear of the classroom, it being preferable to have them both placed in front of the pupils.

We note that the repairing of this building commenced on the 14th instant. It is hoped that the work will be rushed to completion, that the desks will arrive in due time and be set up, and that the classroom will be ready for a teacher to commence duties at an early date.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to the Protestant Indian day school at Caughnawaga. I note that the Rev. Mr. Oke has written to Dr. Manning concerning using for Protestant school purposes the building in which was conducted up to six years ago a school under the joint auspices of the Methodist Missionary Society and this Department. This building belongs to the Department, but shortly after the Protestant work closed, it was used for the purposes of the Roman Catholic school on the Reserve, which is, of course, a Roman Catholic one. When the Protestant school was reopened in 1923, there was, of course, an agitation to use the former building. However, this was now urgently required for the satisfactory conduct of the Roman Catholic Indian school system, and the Department made temporary arrangements to try out the Protestant school again in the Methodist Church. In January, 1924, the Chairman of the Methodist District authorized Mr. Mitchell L. Deere to offer the church to the Department for school purposes, and Dr. Manning concurred in this arrangement. We undertook repairs, and fitted up the building as a classroom.

I believe more classroom accommodation is needed at Caughnawaga, and, as soon as funds can be provided for the purpose, what is considered necessary will be erected. At that time the question of returning the Protestant activity to the building formerly used by them will be given consideration.

Dear Sir:

We are informed that the Roman Catholic authorities of Caughnawaga are removing furnishings from the School Building, situated on the property of the Protestant community there, preparatory to passing the building over for the use of the Protestant School in September next.

As the Protestant people are excluded from public worship because of inadequate accommodation in the old school house, they request me to approach you, to ascertain if the School Building could be handed over at an earlier date than September, as has been suggested. It seems a great hardship to the people that they have to restrain one-half of their people from attending divine service while the other half are occupying the full capacity of their only place of worship.

For about two years there has been a very marked spiritual movement among the Indians there and they are clamoring for suitable accommodation to take full advantage of this favorable condition.

We find a very fine spirit obtaining among the Indians and we believe with the Public School being placed at their disposal for the education of their children and a suitable place of worship, there is promise of a marked advance in the general uplift of this people.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Faithfully yours,

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott & School Branch,

In compliance with instructions given me on the 2nd instant by the Acting Deputy Superintendent General I beg to give you the following information concerning the work required for the repairing of the Protestant School at Caughnawaga, Que.

The building is in need of painting, inside and outside. The estimated cost of this is $250.00. The porches of the entrances are badly demolished and should be reconstructed at a cost of $60.00. A pneumatic water supply system should be provided at a cost of $150.00. The swings which are now on the school grounds should be removed to give more space for a playground at a cost of $10.00. The outside closets are absolutely useless and two separate new ones should be provided at a cost of $120.00. There is no fence around the ground. The cost of erecting a good strong fence around the school lot would be in the neighborhood of $95.00 including the price of two single gates and one double one, also new doors with glazed panel for proposed entrance costing about $20.00.

While at this school my attention was brought by the teacher, Mr. Ray, to the lack of space for a playground. The playground is only about 70 feet square. There is in the rear of the present school grounds a vacant lot measuring about 160 x 70 feet which belongs to the United Church, and which could provide an ideal playground for the pupils. This enlarging of the school property is most advisable for the reason that the road in front of the school will be transformed this year into an international highway, which means that the traffic will be very heavy and I notice that the pupils are now using the highway as a playground. I would, therefore, recommend that some means be taken to provide this school with adequate playgrounds.

I should recommend that if the work above mentioned is authorized that the agent be requested to obtain competitive prices from local contractors and that the work be performed by contract under his immediate supervision.

Water Pan

The water pan is conveniently located at the front where it belongs. It holds a bountiful supply of water and furnishes the necessary volume of humidity. Being placed immediately under the feed door, it is in the easiest possible position for refilling and cleaning.

Enterprise Wood Grate

When wood is burned a special grate is supplied which rests on top of the regular grate bars.

Hot Water Coil

A coil with ample capacity to heat a thirty gallon tank can be readily attached at any time. You will observe that the feed front of the furnace is built to accommodate this coil and connections.

Large Doors

The extra large feed door on this furnace is a great convenience as it enables even large pieces of coal to be put on the fire without trouble. The ash pit door is also roomy. See page 5 for actual sizes.

Casings

Heavy gauge galvanized iron and black iron are the two materials used in the casings of the 600 Series All Cast. The illustration on page 4 shows the Pipeless Furnace casing construction. Outside casing consists of one sheet of galvanized iron whereas the inner casing is constructed of a galvanized iron sheet, a one inch circulating air space and then heavy black iron. The Pipe Furnace, of course, has only one casing consisting of galvanized iron, a circulating one inch air space and heavy black iron lining. The casing construction in both instances is recognized as the most efficient possible to produce. It means heat upstairs where you need it and a comparatively cool cellar.

Made in Both Pipe and Pipeless Style

The 600 Series Enterprise All Cast Furnace is made in two sizes, Nos. 618 and 620 and in two styles — Pipe and Pipeless. In both cases the internal parts which have been described on the previous pages, are the same, the only variation being in the method of casing. The illustration on page 2 shows just how the Pipeless Furnace appears in the cellar. It has one large register in the floor above it. On page 5 you will find the Pipe Furnace shown. Of course, numerous heat pipes are taken off the top casing and cold air brought in at the bottom, the number and size of these pipes depending on the layout of the house or building to be heated. The plan of the building and numerous other factors determine whether the best results can be secured with a Pipeless or Pipe Furnace. To give accurate advice regarding these matters the Enterprise Heating Engineering Department is maintained. They request that a plan be sent them showing the building to be heated. In return they will supply a report stating exactly what type of furnace should be used, what size and explain in detail the layout. This service is FREE and obligates no one to buy. It makes absolutely sure of satisfactory heating and means that when their recommendations are followed the Enterprise Foundry Co. positively guarantee in writing that complete satisfaction will result.
The Last Word

If possible, before buying it would be desirable to see one of these Furnaces. In that way you could verify the statements which we have made. You would find that not in any respect has the case been over-stated. This Furnace will give you heat—lots of it even in the coldest weather. The heated air will contain moisture and no dust or smoke—prime essentials for health and cleanliness. Owing to its all cast construction it will continue to give this service year in and year out.

Fuel consumption will be at least one fifth less than with other Furnaces. The Patent Enterprise Robb Coal Carburetor assures that.

Furthermore, you take no chance in purchasing an Enterprise Furnace as when a plan of your house is sent to the Enterprise Heating Engineering Department and their recommendation followed, a definite written guarantee, which fully protects you, is sent. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant and in reply to say that in accordance with your instructions, arrangements are made in order to have the floor of the Caughnawaga United Church Indian Day School thoroughly scrubbed and when dry, given a coat of floor oil.

I beg to point out that it is somewhat difficult to keep the floor, the walls and windows of this school in a fair state of cleanliness owing to the rowdy conduct of the Indian children during recess. It is now impossible, for instance, to close one of the outside doors because it was put almost out of use by these children. The outside closets are in an untolerable state and it is quite admissible that slovenliness is the proper of the larger number of those children.

As to the question of ventilation, I beg to say that the windows are well provided with ventilators, but, I wonder if they are used or not. A ventilator is also placed unto the chimney at one end of the classroom, it was only lately when this ventilator was forced open for use.

Permit me to add that when this building was used by the R. C. children, there was plenty of ventilation given through the same ventilators which could also be used for by the present class of pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

Translation

Constant, Oct. 27th 1931

Received my telephone message this afternoon informing me that a fire had started this morning about 8 o'clock at the Protestant school of the Caughnawaga village. I wish to make the following report.

The fire started almost immediately after the furnace man had lighted the furnace in the cellar. The fire originated in one of the air ducts to appear in one of the interior walls. We believe that the children had thrown paper in that air duct. Fortunately the alarm was given immediately and it was necessary to break the exterior door and demolish that wall where the fire seemed to extend to the ceiling.

The fire was extinguished but the damages reached about $400.00. I thought I could authorize Miss Cullen, the teacher, to suspend the teaching until she is advised to the contrary. I requested the guardian of the Catholic School, Mr. Robert, to place boards in the broken door as well as the windows so that no one would get in.

We now await your instructions before the school is repaired to reopen the class.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Dr. McGill:

On the Caughnawaga Reserve, near Montreal, the Board of Home Missions owns a lot next door to the church, on which is erected a comfortable square frame house. A few years ago when Mr. Oke was the missionary, he asked for permission to live in Lachine, because he had several children of High School age. This was granted and the house at Caughnawaga rented. On two or three occasions I discussed with Mr. Russell Ferrier the possibility of using this property for the junior class-room in connection with the day school. The difficulty in the situation arose from the fact that it was rented and the congregation were retaining the rentals. However, we have now succeeded in getting the tenant to vacate and I am writing to suggest that it would be in the best interests of all concerned if, when school opens in the fall, the Department were to rent this building from us. The West half on the ground floor would make a very much better school-room than the present one which is in use. The room on the North-East corner would make a good cloak-room for the children and the two teachers could be made very comfortable upstairs. The building is not in good repair, but we are prepared to put it in shape.

This arrangement would be very much more convenient from the standpoint of the teachers, as this building is the first one on the West side of the church, while the senior class-room is the first building on the East side of the church. All the work would then be consolidated in one place.

Will you please be good enough at your earliest convenience to let me know what the attitude of the Department would be towards this proposition and what rent you would like to suggest.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Ottawa, April 25, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, relative to the renting, from the United Church of Canada, of a frame house, situated on a lot next to the church on the Caughnawaga reserve, to be used as a junior classroom in connection with the Protestant Indian Day School. It is noted that the authorities of the United Church would be pleased to have this building placed in good repair and ready for classroom purposes when the school re-opens after the summer holidays on September first, next.

At the present time, the Department is renting from an Indian a building which is used as a junior classroom, for which a rental is paid at the rate of $150 per year. We will have no funds to pay any increase in this amount for the renting of the building referred to by you, and I shall be pleased to be advised if the Church would accept a rental at the above rate or even less. Further, I should request that you inform the Department how this building is heated, whether by stove or furnace, and if there would be storage facilities for fuel, etc.

I may add that the Department is favourably disposed to consider your suggestion for the rental of this building. I should be pleased if you would state the amount of the rental that would be charged and furnish the other information requested. It is noted that, besides a classroom and a cloakroom for the children, comfortable living accommodation could be provided for the two teachers.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Mr. MacKenzie:

Re: Day School Accommodation, Caughnawaga.

One hundred and fifty dollars a year seems to be a very small rental for a building as large as the one under consideration - especially in view of the fact that it will provide not only classroom accommodation but also living accommodation for the teachers. However, we are more interested in the work at Caughnawaga and in the progress of the School than in any other factor at the present time. The two teachers who are there now have created an entirely new atmosphere in the village and, with better accommodation and equipment, will undoubtedly be able to do a superior type of work - both educationally and in extra-curriculum activities. We agree, therefore, to accept a rental at the rate of $150.00 a year beginning September 1st.

I am asking our Superintendent of Missions for a report as to the cost of the alterations which will be required. Just at present the building is being resurfaced. There is a splendid cement foundation under the whole house and a good furnace, with plenty of store room for fuel, food supplies &c. The tenant who has been occupying the building has not been using the furnace. I doubt if it has been in use for the last two years. The reason he gave was that the ground is low and a certain amount of water came into the basement in the spring and fall. Whether this is due to faulty construction or insufficient drainage, we will have to investigate. My personal opinion is that the tenant was heating the building with stoves because it is cheaper.

Our Board will not be in a position to spend any large sum of money in renovations and improvements during 1933, and it may be that we will have to be content with using stoves for the first year. The removal of the partition downstairs and the painting and decorating of the whole house will cost us quite a sum.

Trusting that this information will be satisfactory and assuring you that we appreciate your cooperation, I am

Yours sincerely,

KJB.MLT
Ottawa, May 2nd, 1933.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is making arrangements with the authorities of the United Church of Canada for the rental, as from the first of September next, of a frame house situated on a lot on the west side of the United Church - the senior classes being conducted in the first building on the east side of the Church. The west half of the ground floor of this building will make a much better classroom than the one which is at present in use and which is rented from Mrs. Atreno.

I have to request, therefore, that you will give Mrs. Sak Atreno notice that the department will not require the building which was rented from her for classroom purposes after the first of September next. At that time, you should forward a voucher, in triplicate, properly certified for the balance of the rental due her to the date the lease terminates.

The United Church authorities will arrange to have the necessary repairs and alterations carried out to the frame house. Dear Sir,

Permit me to refer to your letter of the end of last month concerning the new installation of desks, etc., to be made during the course of the next two months in the building of the United Church Mission at Caughnawaga.

In the third paragraph of your letter you informed me that there is already a good furnace in the basement of that building. In fact there is a furnace, but unless the radiators, which were removed, are reinstalled that furnace will be of no use for the heating of the school.

Unless the Department intends to install a new kind of furnace (Quebec heater) which was used last year in the house of Mrs. Atrenho, this furnace would be then useless and it would be, furthermore, an economy in the purchase of coal, because I foresee that if the Mission is to reinstall the radiators, the furnace in the cellar will consume a large quantity of coal, while the use of the Quebec Heater in the classroom would only need from 6 to 7 tons of coal.

However, there is also the question of knowing whether the teachers will dwell in the upper part of this building, and if such is the case the Department will have to heat the whole building. Dear Mr. Sutherland:

As you know, our two teachers at Caughnawaga for the last three years have been boarding with an Indian family. The arrangement is not satisfactory. Miss Daly was here on her way home for vacation and we discussed the problem at some length. There seems nothing to do except provide them with a residence. Mike Skye owns the house next to the senior classroom and it is available for rent, as he is living at the present time with his mother. The house appears to be fairly well built and with a little decorating inside could be made quite comfortable. We can rent it for $100.00 a year. Would the Department be willing to pay the rent if The United Church of Canada furnishes the residence for these teachers?

While I am writing about Caughnawaga, I may say that I visited recently the building which is rented from the United Church for a junior classroom. We have a committee at work on it now and hope by the time school opens that a proper system of drainage will be installed and that a sufficient amount of redecorating and painting will have been done to make the part used as a schoolroom more attractive.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Dear Mr. Sutherland: Re: Accommodation, Junior Room,
Caughnawaga Day School, P. Q.

In connection with the meeting of the Executive Committee of our Board, which was held last week, we had a discussion with the Superintendent of Missions for the Montreal-Ottawa area concerning the accommodation for our missionary on the Caughnawaga-Oka field, Rev. C. J. Dean. He is finding the cost of working his field prohibitive and we are being asked to spend a considerable sum of money in renovating the Caughnawaga house, now being used as a school-room, so that it will be available for his use by September lst. It will therefore be necessary for the Department to find some other accommodation for Miss Daly's class, which is now being housed in that building.

I would like to make a suggestion, namely, that your architect seriously consider re-modelling the senior class-room, now being used by Miss Kenner. By lowering the ceiling 3 feet and putting an extension of about 6 feet on the back of the building, two splendid class-rooms could be provided on the ground floor and an excellent apartment prepared for the teachers upstairs. The Department is now paying $22.50 a month rent to provide for the junior room and the teachers. The change could be effected for an expenditure of about $3500.00.

I hope to be in Ottawa on Monday next and to have the privilege of discussing this and some other problems with you.

Yours very sincerely,

KJB.MLT

Dear Sir;-

In connection with the renting of a house at Caughnawaga, for the purpose of new accommodation for the junior class of the Protestant School, I wish that the houses visited by the Rev. Mr. Dean and myself were not found suitable for the purpose required.

Rev. Mr. Dean expressed his dissatisfaction of not being provided with a place meeting with the standards and specifications required for the number of pupils of that class etc., and gave me to understand that he was leaving everything to the Department, stating that there were no private dwellings which could be used as a school.

However, owing to the situation in regard to the matter I interviewed Reverend Sister M. Cleophas, Principal of the R.C. Schools, in order to find out if room could not be found for Miss. Daly's class, for at least a year, at any of the R.C. Village Schools.

The Rev. Principal advised me today, that in order to oblige the Department, it would be possible to accommodate the Junior class of the Protestant School, at the Eastern School. The Sister states that by combining the two preparatory classes of the Eastern and the Kathari Schools together, she could manage to let Miss. Daly have the use of one class of the Eastern School. It being understood, however, that this arrangement will only be temporary, as the Sisters will badly need this room for the 1937-38 school term.

I would recommend the acceptation of the Rev. Sister's offer for the next school year. In the meantime, it might be possible to find some other quarters for 1937.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

It cannot provide the essential requirements of a healthy class-room, because in a healthy class-room it is necessary to have:

1. Plenty of fresh air,
2. Sufficient amount of light and
3. Direct sunlight for a part of each day.

I am sure you will agree with me that these three essential requirements of a healthy class-room are wholly lacking in this church.

It is really so dark in this church I have much fear for the coming impairment of the eye-sight, too, of school children if classes are allowed in this church.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

Accompanied by the Departmental Architect, Mr. Phelan visited the Caughnawaga Reserve on the 11th instant, in connection with the proposed erection of an addition to the Caughnawaga United Church School.

Mr. Dean told Mr. Phelan that the Indian trustees of the land held by the United Church are opposed to using any of the church land for a new school, as these Indian trustees state that it is their intention to erect a community hall, and they feel that if a new school building is erected on the property and additional land made available for playground purposes, there will not be sufficient land left for the erection of a community hall.

Mr. Phelan pointed out to Mr. Dean that we were only able to provide the sum of $3,500.00 in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new building and there are no funds available to consider purchase of a site for the purpose. Unless a site is made available on the church property, it will not be possible to proceed this year. I feel you will agree with me that it would be unfortunate if building operations this year were prevented by a dispute regarding the site.

I am therefore submitting the whole matter to you as we would appreciate having a definite statement on file, indicating that the Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada formally grants permission to the Department to erect a new building on the land now used for school purposes and that an additional part of your property will be made available.

Our Architect suggests a new building, at right angles to the present school building and parallel with the fence separating the school lot from the church. MEMORANDUM:

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Accompanied by the Architect, Mr. J. E. Dudley, I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve last night and met the Board of Management of the United Church of Canada with reference to the proposed new classroom.

There were present at the meeting Reverend Mr. Dean, Mr. Skye, Mr. Patton, Mr. Delisle, Mr. Lazore, Mr. Moses Diabo, Sr., Mr. Montour and Miss Skye. Mr. Dean acted as Chairman and Miss Skye as Interpreter. Indian Agent Brisebois also attended.

I first explained to the meeting that we had $3,500 available for the erection of a new classroom but that our Architect felt that this amount was only sufficient for the erection of a building separate from the present school and that it would not be possible, with the amount at our disposal, to erect the second classroom in such a manner that it would provide a community center. Mr. Dudley also explained to those present the reasons why it was only possible to erect a separate classroom.

Reverend Mr. Dean expressed the view that the Department was endeavoring to side-step its responsibility for a minority group inasmuch as he did not make any attempt to purchase a site and erect a school. I pointed out to him that the amount at our disposal only allowed the erection of a building and that we have no funds for the purchase of a site. He further expressed the opinion that the Indians felt that the Department should not expect them to provide a location for the school on the church property. I replied to this by stating that we were endeavoring to provide proper educational facilities for their children and we felt, therefore, that they should cooperate to the extent of allowing us to build on the church property which is not being used for any other purpose.

Miss Skye, speaking for the Indians, expressed the opinion that it would be preferable not to erect another building on the church property as the Indians hoped to erect a community hall on this property in the near future.

After considerable discussion it was quite apparent that the Indians were opposed to the erection of a new single classroom on the church property and, furthermore, Mr. Dean stated that they had recently decided to request the Department to again rent the church as a second classroom for the academic year 1937-38.

In view of the above, I can see no advantage in giving any further consideration to the erection of a second classroom for the Caughnawaga U. C. School this year and I would recommend that the matter be dropped for the present.
July 21st, 1937.

I replied to this by saying that we were endeavouring to provide proper educational facilities for their children and we felt, therefore, that they should cooperate to the extent of allowing us to build on the church property which is not being used for any other purpose.

Miss Skye, speaking for the Indians, expressed the opinion that it would be preferable not to erect another building on the church property as the Indians hoped to erect a community hall on this property in the near future.

After considerable discussion, it was quite apparent that the Indians were opposed to the erection of a new single classroom on the church property and, furthermore, Mr. Dean stated that they had recently decided to request the Department to again rent the church as a second classroom for the academic year 1937-38.

In view of the above, I can see no advantage in giving any further consideration to the erection of a second classroom for the Caughnawaga U. C. School this year and I would recommend that the matter be dropped for the present.

Memorandum: Mr. Mills.

Re: Proposed Day School at Caughnawaga, Que.

As requested I accompanied Mr. Phalen of the Welfare and Training Service, Indian Affairs Branch, to Caughnawaga in connection with the above school. The proposition submitted for the existing school is to connect an additional room to the present schoolroom, using a folding partition, so that the two rooms could be used as one large room.

This building is situated on the North-east corner of the lot, excluding any possibility of additions to the North and East sides of the building. The space on the West side of the school, which would be the logical point of extension, in view of the construction of the school, is but 20 feet. This length combined with the width of the building would not be sufficient to provide a classroom for 40 to 50 children. An addition to the South wall would necessitate placing the classrooms side by side in order to secure light. This would require a width of at least 44 feet, and as the main portion of the building is only 30 feet wide, it would require complete rebuilding of the south side of the building. The expense of this work would be excessive of the funds provided.

Objections were raised to the crowding of the existing Church located on the West side of the school, and the question of the addition was left in abeyance pending a decision on a site, and the advisability of attempting to alter the existing building.

I understand from Mr. Phalen of the Welfare and Training Service, Indian Affairs, that the Indian Affairs Branch will advise the Survey and Engineering Branch that this work is to be cancelled.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. J.M. Wardle  
Director, Surveys & Engineering Branch

Ottawa, December 30, 1937.

In our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39, provision is being made for an amount of $5,000, for the erection of an addition to the Caughnawaga United Church Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, Quebec. If possible, we desire this addition erected in such a manner that it will permit of both rooms being used from time to time as a community centre.

As Mr. Dudley visited the Caughnawaga Reserve during the summer of 1937, he is fully aware of what the Department desires at this place.

I would appreciate your submitting a sketch plan of what you consider might be suitable.

Director.

PROPOSED BUILDING DATA

NAME OF BUILDING: Day School, Addition United Church.

LOCATION: Caughnawaga Indian Reserve.

BRANCH: Indian Affairs

APPROPRIATION: $5,000.00

RECOMMEND CONSTRUCTION BY: DAY LABOUR Yes

REASON: CLASS OF INDIAN DAY LABOUR AVAILABLE.

Laborers, carpenters and electrician.

BUILDING REQUIREMENTS: ROOMS AND ACCOMMODATION; NUMBER OF PUPILS;

TYPE OF CONSTRUCTION:

Alteration to existing building to provide two classrooms
with folding connecting doors to allow use of rooms as
Community Hall. Rooms to accommodate 65 pupils.

Existing building frame construction.

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT;
NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS.

Village Holding No. 623, Area 44 perches, Soil, gravel. Lot well drained.

WATER SUPPLY: SYSTEM REQUIRED; SOURCE OF WATER, ETC.

Artesian well to be bored.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6074, file 304-5, part 4)
TOILET FACILITIES: SEWAGE DISPOSAL; SYSTEM REQUIRED; LOCATION.

At present the toilets are located outside of existing building. If inside toilets are built a septic tank will be needed.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.

The building is heated by a hot-air furnace. The existing furnace is believed adequate for the heating of the present class and the projected extension.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.

The building is already lighted with electricity. The service being supplied by the Shawinigan Water & Power Co.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.

Blackboard 10 by 4. About 30 school desks and benches will be required. Cupboards also.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.

Adirondacks Junction. C.P.R. From R.R. Station, trucks can be used.

REMARKS:

If at all possible I would suggest that three of four rooms be added on the upstairs which would be used by teachers as living quarters. This would save the Department the paying of rental and fuel, as it could be heated together with class rooms at no additional cost.

It is very difficult to find suitable quarters at Caughnawaga for residence.

Memorandum:

Mr. Mills,

Re - Addition to Caughnawaga United Church Day School.

In reference to your memorandum of May 11th asking for instructions in regard to calling for tenders for the construction of the above building by contract, it has been decided by the Department that the building is to be constructed by day labour. It is understood from our telephone conversation this morning that there are no serious objections to this procedure but that it will involve additional work by your limited architectural staff in preparing bills of material from which purchases will be made; also that the Engineer will have to have authority when on the ground to make such emergency purchases as may be required when the work is under way.

Under the circumstances, will you kindly take action on this basis as soon as possible. As soon as bills of material are ready, they should be submitted to the Purchasing Agent for his action.

The Director of the Indian Affairs Branch advises me that Indian labour will be available for this work and should be utilized as far as possible.

Kindly note that Mr. Josephat David, of Woodlands, Quebec, is to be employed as foreman-carpenter. You might look into the question of a suitable rate for this position.

Director.

Reverend Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, in which you refer to your communication of April 16th, regarding the motion passed by the Trustee Board of the Montreal Presbytery, United Church of Canada.

On reviewing this motion, it is felt the request for us to lease the land for a period of fifteen years is rather unusual. The Board of Home Missions of the United Church has been associated with the Department for several years in the conduct of various schools and always dealt very fairly with us. In the present instance we feel that any additional land that may be necessary in view of the erection of the new addition to the school should be transferred to us without cost for use for school purposes as long as required. Otherwise the Department could hardly be expected to erect a building on land to which we would only have title for a limited term.

Good blackboards will be placed in this school and a fence will be built. If funds will permit, indoor toilets will also be provided. Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to my letter of the 1st instant dealing with the temporary arrangements made for the two classes of the United Church Indian Day School and to your telegram dated September 3rd, in which approval was given to the use of the U.C. Church building for one class and the use of one room in the Kateri School for the other. In this connection I beg to make the following report.

On receipt of your telegram I communicated with Miss Bryan, teacher of the Senior class and instructed her of your decision. She was quite pleased with the arrangements. Rev. Mr. Dean was also informed. He expressed the opinion that the parents might not be willing to send their children at that school.

The school opened on the 6th and on that day only four pupils out of 22 went to the senior class, on the 7th, only two, on the 8th and the 9th three were present.

Several meetings of the parents whose children are attending that class were held in the course of this week at which meetings it was apparently decided not to allow their children to attend. It seems that if the parents do not send their children to school it is due to the fact that they have not been advised to do so very strongly, if at all advised in that way.

Another aspect to the situation is that there seems to be a campaign going on against Miss Bryan, who teaches in the above school and who has tried hard to persuade the parents of the children to send them to school. She is accused of disloyalty, etc., because of her willingness to teach in this building.

The contention
The contention is that she should have refused to teach at the Kateri School. This is unfair if we consider that the teacher is simply cooperating with us and following her instructions.

With regard to the attendance I would ask you to send me specific instructions to that effect. Should the parents be notified in accordance with the Indian Act and arrested if they fail to comply with their notifications? Or should matters be allowed to remain as they are, that is, to teach to the few pupils attending, instead of discontinuing. The first above mentioned course would have been followed under ordinary circumstances but owing to the situation nothing was done, as it would have likely brought unpleasant and unnecessary publicity.

Kindly let me have your views in the matter.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Referring to the matter which our delegation from the Montreal Presbytery discussed with you and Messrs Hoey and Phelan today, I am submitting herewith the request which we presented at the request of our Presbytery.

With our concern for the welfare of our work at Caughnawaga, educational, and religious, we are deeply appreciative of the work being done by the Department to give more adequate school facilities for the Protestant Indian children.

Our temporary problem is the care of these school children while the building improvements are in process. The arrangement of your Department to have one of these classes taught in our Church building is entirely satisfactory but the provision for the other class in a room at the Roman Catholic School is proving the occasion of embarrassment and serious disturbing of our work.

The difficulty is a local one and arises from advantage being taken of the arrangement, to press the claims of the Roman Catholic Church on our Protestant children. We recognize that this has its roots in what one of your assistants described today as an "old feud", but feel that we have to face the conditions as they exist and set ourselves, by constructive and non-provocative means, to bring the conflicting elements into relationships of good will.

To this end we are prepared to place at the disposal of the Department a large room in our Mission house where a larger class than the present one was housed on a former occasion. There would be no cost to the Department other than the necessary remuneration for the janitor for the care of the room, and our groups would be centred about our own property and the unity of our work maintained.
Any further details regarding our position came out in the discussion today and are familiar to you. We understand better than before our visit to you, the actions you have taken so far, but we regret that our interests were not consulted before anything was done.

We trust this matter will have early and sympathetic consideration of the Department and thank you for your kindness and courtesy in receiving us today.

I am,

Very sincerely yours,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

I am sending forward herewith, for your consideration, copy of a letter received by me from the Reverend James D. McCrae, Chairman of the Montreal Presbytery of the United Church of Canada. This letter was written in response to a suggestion I made when a delegation representing the United Church discussed with me and certain officials of the Training Division the available school accommodation at the Caughnawaga reserve. This delegation interviewed me on Monday the 12th of September.

I may state by way of explanation that provision was made in the estimates of this year for the construction of an additional classroom at the Indian Day School conducted by the Department in cooperation with the United Church on the Caughnawaga reserve. The work of reconstruction was undertaken the latter part of July by the Surveys and Engineering Branch and will, in all probability, be completed toward the end of October. In the meantime, provision had to be made for the pupils of the senior and junior classrooms. It was finally decided that one class should be conducted in the United Church and the other in a classroom offered by the Principal of the large school operated by the Department in cooperation with the Catholic Church.

The members of the delegation representing the Montreal Presbytery protested rather vigorously against this arrangement. It was their contention that

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6074, file 304-5, part 4)

CANADA
the senior classroom, now conducted in the Catholic school, should be conducted in the home of the Missionary. A room in this home had been offered to us at a rental fee of $20.00 a month. I informed them that I was not prepared to abandon the present arrangement and adopt their suggestion. I did promise, however, that if they presented their request to me in writing, the matter would be sent forward to the Minister for consideration and final decision.

It should be pointed out that the present arrangement is a temporary one and that the building in the classroom of which the senior pupils are now receiving instruction is the property of the Government. The agent informs me that the present arrangement is quite satisfactory to the teachers and particularly the teacher of the senior classroom, who naturally prefers a regular classroom to a room in the home of the Missionary.

As a department, we are not primarily interested in missionary effort on Indian reserves, and I cannot remember that we have ever at any time sought to dictate to the churches how their missionary work on our reserves should be conducted. The matter now under consideration is purely one of educational administration and is one which, in my judgment, lies wholly beyond the jurisdiction of the United Church and its officials. If we concede the right of a particular church to dictate or even give direction with respect to the use of school buildings, the task of administering our schools will become an exceedingly difficult and exacting one.

I may state that immediately following my discussion with the members of the delegation the officials communicated with the Surveys and Engineering Branch and obtained from them an assurance that the work on the school building would be pushed forward with the object of having the building completed at the earliest possible date.

I shall await your instructions and the decision of the Minister with respect to this matter.

Director.

January 26, 1939.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: New United Church Day School at Caughnawaga, P.Q.

I beg to advise that a new well has been drilled to supply water to the above mentioned school, which work was completed at the beginning of last month. It was necessary to install this new well to replace the old one which had been abandoned owing to its contaminated condition and other causes. It was carried down to a depth of 65 feet in order to obtain an adequate quantity of water to supply the new plumbing system in the new addition, toilets, etc.

As I understand that no bacteriological or chemical analysis has yet been made of the water from the well in question, it is suggested that the Indian Affairs Branch be advised to have an analysis made of the water from one of the taps in the school. This could be attended to by obtaining the regular sterilized sample bottles from the Quebec Ministry of Health, 80 Notre Dame Street East, Montreal, P.Q. The samples of the water could be taken by the Indian Agent in company with the Reserve Doctor. I might say that there is no harm attached to such analyses and the two samples necessary could be taken to the Provincial Laboratory in Montreal by either the Indian Agent or the Chief Constable, who, I understand, make daily trips to Montreal on departmental business.

Should the results of the analyses be found unsatisfactory, this Service could, if requested, give some directions as to the manner in which the new well could be disinfected at a very low cost.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of the 22nd of May last, in which you requested to be supplied with estimates towards the erection of a good substantial fence between the school grounds of the United Church and the other properties.

In reply I wish to transmit you herewith estimates which have been obtained through Mr. J.F. Crepin, a merchant from Chateauguay Bassin who is on the approved list. These estimates are for a fence 5 feet in height. Estimate No. 1, is for a fence as shown on page 6 of the enclosed catalogue and is comprising steel posts, steel frame, completely installed by the Company.

Estimate No. 2, is for the wire only, and in connection with this estimate I wish to say that this could be put up by using wooden fence posts and wooden frame. In addition to the wire the following material would be required: 56 posts of 6" x 6", 8 feet long at .90 each; 1150 linear feet of scantling 2" x 4" at $2.50 per thousand feet. If a first class job is wanted it would be advisable to set the posts in cement and it is estimated that half a bag of cement per post would be required at an approximate price of $.65 or $.70 a bag. The sand and the crushed stone would be available without cost.

The labour for the erection of the fence by Indians is estimated at about $55.00.

The prices obtained were from J.F. Crepin of Chateauguay Basin and Leduc & Fils of Beauharnois, Que., both dealers on the approved list. It will be noted that the fence to be made is on the east, west and south part of the lot as only the front part is in good condition.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to you letter of the 8th instant dealing with the construction of a fence around the U.C. Indian Day School ground.

As the estimates already submitted were found too high, I wish to submit you other estimates at reduced cost.

Chain link fencing 4' high, 2" links, would cost $24.48 a foot for a total of $131.76 galvanized before being cut. The previous estimate was for a 5 feet high chain link fence. Instead of 56 square posts 6" x 6", 8 feet long at $.90 each, ordinary fence posts as used on farms could be purchased at $.15 each for a total of $8.40. In order to further reduce the cost the wooden frame could be eliminated and approximately 150 feet of scantling used for bracing. No cement will be used for the posts.

As to the possibility of having Indians on relief to do the work without cost I may say that this is not considered possible as they do not even do any work for their church without being paid. If the framing, the cement are eliminated and shorter posts used it is estimated that the cost of labor will be of $30. only instead of $55.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

I wish to inform you that the house which was for the past few years occupied by the teachers of the United Church Indian Day School will not be available for them on the last of September next, as the owner who was overseas with the Canadian Army has returned and will occupy same with his family.

However another house has been found for the teachers for the next School year. This house is located on the Highway about 500 feet from the School, the property of Mr. Joseph Lefebvre an Indian who lives in the United States. This house is very comfortable, has five rooms and is completely furnished.

Mr. Lefebvre was willing to rent and as he was leaving for Brooklyn on this date I took the liberty of having the enclosed agreement made before his departure.

The teachers have visited this house before the end of the School year and had requested me to try to rent same as they were entirely satisfied with it. It is not believed that any other furnished house would be available on the Reserve.

(Fr. Brisebois)

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant dealing with the painting of the U.C. Indian Day School.

Relative to the price given I may say that under ordinary circumstances this would be high, but this includes the scraping of the building which is in a bad state as the old paint is all peeling off.

The following material will be needed,

- 12 Gallons of Paint (Buff color)
- 3 " White
- 3 " turpentine
- 1 " oil
- 20 " Stain for roof. (Green)
- 25 lbs putty
- 1½ gall. Paint for porch (Grey)

It would be appreciated if the above material could be obtained as soon as possible so that this work be completed before the reopening of the school.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Gaughnawage United Church,
