June 2, 1947.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Gaughnawage, Que.

Dear Sir:

Would you please be so kind as to forward the following suggestion and request to the proper authorities in the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Board of Stewards of the Gaughnawage United Church is interested in buying a 16mm sound projector for the presentation of motion pictures. From the church viewpoint the reasons are as follows: 1) It can be used to show religious pictures; 2) it can also be a means of providing proper entertainment for our people on the reserve.

The main reason for our interest, however, is in the education of our children. If the United Church School had the use of a projector for educational purposes, we can provide an even better education than is possible at present. As you may know, many of our children are hoping to attend high school on the Island of Montreal. If we do not have the necessary aids to education here, they are decidedly handicapped when they have to compete with other youngsters who have had better opportunities.

Since the provision of educational aids is the responsibility of the Department of Indian Affairs, we feel that it is only reasonable to request that the Department of Indian Affairs should pay at least half the costs of the projector. I feel sure that when the Department gives this suggestion the consideration which it deserves they will be pleased to assist us in our work of raising the educational and living standards of our people.

Having had four years experience with all makes of 16mm projectors, there are only two which I would recommend - the Bell-Howell and the Audio-Visual Educator. These machines are by far the best in the field. Of the two, I would buy the Audio-Visual Educator for the simple reason that it is a Canadian machine made in Canada by Canadians. The Audio-Visual Educator is manufactured by the Northern Tool and Gauge Limited, Eastview (Ottawa), Ontario and is distributed by the Audio-Visual Educator Limited, 160 McArthur Road, Eastview, Ont. The price complete is $585.00. However, they have a special price of $465.00 for schools and churches.

Yours truly,

J. Stanley Kennedy,
Student-minister in charge.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.,

Rev. Mr. Kennedy of the local United Church Mission has on this date applied to be supplied with the necessary materials for the construction of a skating rink on the grounds of the U.C. Indian Day School for use of the pupils and also of the adults of this vicinity.

As you are aware there are no rinks for the children attending the local Schools nor are there any other outdoor amusements. It is believed that this request is in the best interest of the children.

The cost of the boards, scantlings, nails etc., for the proposed rink of 150 by 60, would be approximately $170.00, exclusive of labour. It has been suggested that the boards be made in panels of 12 feet long which could be used every year thus doing away with any carpenter work.

Mr. Kennedy would undertake to supervise the activities of the children and others using the rink.

Will you please advise if this request could be granted.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois, Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, we regret that owing to lack of funds we are not prepared to allow the amount requested in your letter for constructing a skating rink on the grounds of the Caughnawaga U.C. School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Caughnawaga, Que.,
December 3, 1947.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dep., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to advise that the kitchen stove in use at the residence of the teachers of the local U.C. Indian Day School is now out of order and cannot be repaired. It is a stove which has been in use since over 30 years. This stove is not the property of the Department but that of the owner of the house, Mr. Jos. Lefebvre.

Miss Daly the Principal of the U.C. School informs that she has found a stove suitable for their use at J.A. Tessier, Lachine, Que., which could be delivered immediately.

Said stove is made by "Belanger Ltd.", model Marina, white enamel, six lids, water tank and dish warmer etc., The price complete would be of $170.00. Without hot water tank the price would be of $150.00.

I would appreciate being informed if this purchase would meet with your approval so that the teachers be informed accordingly.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Caughnawaga, Que.

Dear Mr. Breebold,

We, the undersigned teachers of the Day School under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, wish to thank you for the kind attention you gave to supplying recently, through the Department certain repairs and equipment necessary for efficiency and our personal comfort, in the schoolrooms as well as in the dwelling house supplied to us.

We would particularly draw your attention to the satisfaction we now have in the janitor service. Mr. Whitebean, who has replaced Mr. Pendle, has by his efforts changed the whole atmosphere of our classrooms. He has scrubbed and disinfected floors, walls and ceilings throughout, which has not been done for years. Each week he scrubs one classroom in turn with disinfectant, which is necessary for the health of the pupils. Since Christmas he has painted the floors of the senior school. Mr. Whitebean's willingness to co-operate in the interest of our children is commendable.

However, with all this satisfaction realized, we feel justified
in appealing to the Department through your good offices for further consideration—this time more especially as to our personal comfort.

As you are aware we are housed on the Reserve in quarters rented furnished from one of the Indians of the Band. The furnishings while moderately comfortable are not complete by any means.

Now that there are three of us living here it is almost imperative that we have an adequate refrigeration unit in order to properly keep our food.

Laundry facilities have been most inadequate. So far we have sent our heavier pieces to a laundry in Montreal which has proved unsatisfactory and expensive. We understand that this expense is being taken care of for other teacherages by the Department. In lieu of this we request the Department to give consideration to supplying us with an up-to-date washing machine.

This request then is for the following:

One electric refrigerator of a capacity of at least 7 cubic feet.

One electric washing machine—standard type.

We have not made such a request previously because it has been generally known that such equipment has been in short supply.

These articles, along with others already supplied, being Departmental property, will be useful for years and transferable to a new teacherage when such a building is available.

An extra copy of this letter is supplied, if in your judgment, a copy should be submitted to the Department.

Yours truly,

E.W. Roberts

Director,
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Ont.

Re: Refrigerator for Teacherage
United Church School

Replying to your letter dated April 21st, in which we are advised "We are not prepared to supply an Electric Refrigerator. However, if ice can be obtained --- we are prepared to supply an ice box on the understanding that the teachers would purchase their own ice."

On the strength of your letter dated February 25th, 1946, the teachers for the United Church Day School were advised that in all probability their request would be granted in the fiscal year 1946-47, and information was received with much pleasure and anticipation. In this connection I wish to point out that the teachers for this school have done through the years, been very moderate in their requests, and have not always had all the comforts which their position may warrant.

The request for an Electric Refrigerator does in our judgment warrant favourable consideration for the following reasons:

(a) The fact that nearly all the uptodate homes on this reserve have Electric machines, the demand for ice delivery has fallen so low that the convenient supply is not available, and no deliveries appear until June, and usually close down after September 1st.

(b) There are now three lady teachers living in the U.C. Teacherage, with the prospect that a fourth will necessary for the next term.

It should not be considered unreasonable for these women to desire to have necessary uptodate conveniences such as they would have in their own homes, especially, when ice is purchased in more or less large quantities, a week's supply - either in Montreal or the convenient small towns, and these women are required to live on the Reserve, and in these modern days refrigeration is considered an all year round daily necessity.

(c) Further to the fact that most homes today are equipped with Electric Refrigerators, it may be well to recognize that the other Teacherage on the Reserve, as
well as the residence leased for the Royal Canadian Police on the Reserve, have already Electric Refrigerator supplied by the Department, installed and which have been and are now main-
tained by our Department.

I would, under the circumstances most strongly recommend a reconsideration, and that the request for an Electric Refrigerator be granted, especially when, as previously indicated one may be purchased wholesale by the Department.

Frs. Brisebois,
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Miss Daly, Principal of the local U.C. Indian Day School has requested the redecorating of the Teacherage which comprises four rooms and a bathroom.

As you are aware we are renting this house from an Indian of the Reserve, Mr. Joseph Lefebvre who is residing at Brooklyn, N.Y., Mr. Lefebvre refused to undertake this work unless his rental is increased by $10.00 or $15.00 per month.

This increase is believed to be exorbitant. Will you please let me know if the Branch would undertake to redecorate this residence. The rental of this house is of $30.00 per month.

(Frs. Brisebois)

Le livre décrit la vie des hommes qui habitent les régions suivantes : l'Arabie, le désert du Sahara, la Chine, l'Afrique du Sud, la vallée du Congo, la Suède, la Norvège, les Pays-Bas, le pays des Esquimaux, la Laponie, l'Antarctique, l'Inde, la Chine et le Japon.

Il est écrit en un langage adapté au développement intellectuel des enfants de troisième et de quatrième années. Outre le texte qui décrit la vie des habitants des différents pays énumérés, l'ouvrage contient de belles illustrations qui permettent de mieux comprendre les peuples décrits, leurs habitats, leurs occupations, leurs moyens de transport. Il indique aussi les recherches qu'on peut faire faire aux élèves et les travaux qu'on peut leur assigner pour faire cette étude de géographie humaine d'après la méthode active.

PEUPLES LOINTAINS a été préparé par une institutrice qui connaît parfaitement son sujet et possède une grande expérience de l'enseignement. La version française est due à la plume de Dr. Louis Charbonneau d'Ottawa.

Toutes les écoles du Canada trouveront profit à se servir de cet excellent ouvrage.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Gaughnawaga Indian Day School

You will recall previous correspondence concerning our plans for converting the Gaughnawaga Eastern School for use by the United Church children, when it is no longer required by the Roman Catholic children.

When our Engineer visits these schools, as requested, would he please carefully investigate the heating problems. We have just received a letter from the Student Missionary at Gaughnawaga, Mr. J. S. Kennedy, reading as follows:

"Since the heating unit in the present United Church school will have to be changed; and since our Board of Home Missions must renew the heating unit in the church building this year; and since the heating unit in the minister's residence must be replaced within two to five years, therefore, we feel that there might be some way in which your Department and our Board of Home Missions could cooperate in installing a central heating unit for the three buildings.

"This suggestion is feasible due to the short distance between the buildings.

"As you know, it is less expensive to heat three buildings from one central unit than from three..."
units. The cost of operation to your department, to the church, and to the house could be determined quite easily from the cubic content of each building.

"If this suggestion is of interest to you, we would be pleased to have a qualified and reliable heating engineer inspect the three buildings and recommend the type of heating unit which would provide the most efficiency with the least cost. By the time this would be done, Dr. Dorey should have returned to Toronto and details of installation cost could be arranged between yourself and him."

When your engineer visits this school, we would appreciate his comments concerning the feasibility of Mr. Kennedy's suggestions.

Director.

May 23rd, 1949
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Dept., Of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As a Councillor of Caughnawaga, I wish to convey the wishes of my people and especially the councillors that are illiterate, (Can't read, can't write and can't talk English or French). I wish on behalf of these people, to protest the actions of the present Council, by passing resolutions and By Laws without discussion and without the consent of the individual Councillor. These resolutions and By Laws are passed without translation or explanation so that there are some who don't know what is going on. These under-handed actions must stop in order to get the full co-operation of the Council and Band.

On behalf of these people I wish to protest a Resolution passed at this month's meeting, in which the New School was mentioned. This Resolution asks for a Catholic School and to be controlled by the Church, I protested this.

Well, what will become of the children of other faiths? Our representative before the mixed committee requested a Public School, that will be of benefit to all our children without discrimination as to faith. Our representative at that time carried out the wishes of the Band, and we wish that nothing be changed.

We wish this institution to be a symbol of Democracy (freedom of religion) to be of benefit to all. Thanking you in advance for your co-operation.

I remain,

Yours truly,

(Sgd) C. Albany.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, May 25, 1949

Re: Eastern Day School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Que.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of March 29th bearing your notation of the 31st instant in connection with the above, you are advised that our heating engineer made an inspection of the mechanical services on May 20th.

The building was erected in 1912 and is generally in a good state of preservation. Some superficial structural repairs should be made to the porches and stairs. Painting and decorating repairs would add greatly to the all round appearance, both inside and out.

The heating system was reported to be unsatisfactory. The first floor can be kept reasonably warm but the second floor is almost impossible to heat. This condition has existed for many years according to information given to our officer.

The system is a conglomerate combination, one and two pipe low pressure steam, served by a square sectional cast iron steam boiler and it was installed when the building was erected. The distribution piping was connected in a haphazard and unorthodox manner, and the pipe hook-up at the boiler is incorrect to say the least. In addition to the foregoing, the boiler is unfit for further service, as leaks have developed and the base has failed.

In a previous memorandum from Major Mackay, it was suggested that the Superintendent of Indian Education be contacted before this inspection was carried out. As a consequence, Col. Neary, verbally requested our officer to investigate the possibility of installing plumbing and water service in the building.

Our engineer found a 180 gallon water pressure tank in the basement in apparently good condition with a nearly new water pump and this equipment was functioning quite satisfactorily. The well has produced water in ample capacity to date, and there seems to be no doubt of a continued supply.

Further investigation revealed that it would be possible to install toilets and wash basins in the cloak rooms together with a kitchen sink and a separate lavatory for the teachers. The student missionary, Mr. J.S. Kennedy, agreed to the use of this space and suggested to our officer that cloak room accommodation could be found elsewhere. It remains only to carry out a soil absorption test to determine the nature of the soil in order to design a septic tank and sewage disposal field.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Commenting on the third paragraph in Major Mackay's memorandum of March 29th, it can definitely be stated that it would not be practicable to attempt to heat the present United Church School and the Ministry Road Transit Testing plant of the Eastern School. The initial cost would be prohibitive, and it would involve extensive operations which could not be economically justified in a set up of this kind. As a result of the investigations, it is recommended that the following operations be carried out at the Eastern School with reference to the plumbing and heating.

Install new plumbing fixtures in cloak rooms where shown including 3 W.C.'s and 3 basins on boys side and 3 W.C.'s basins on girls side with a kitchen sink. These fixtures shall be piped from the existing pressure tank. Provide one domestic hot water storage tank of approximately 100 gallon capacity with immersion electric heaters.

Provide concrete septic tank and sewage disposal bed.

Install new cast iron boiler, new steam and return mains with necessary traps and other accessories, new condensation pump and new return risers to the existing radiators on the second floor.

While it is impossible to form an accurate estimate of the cost until a detailed layout has been made, it is felt that the above operations will involve an amount of approximately $6,500.00.

This Division will prepare plans and specifications covering the above work as soon as other commitments will permit at which time you will be further advised.

Chas. H. Buck,
For Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.
Mr. B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re Staff - Saughnawage U.C. School.

Miss Burden sounds like a fairly good prospect and I shall be pleased to give her any information she may desire.

Miss Ratton visited Saughnawage on Saturday morning, July 16th. I must say that she seems somewhat better than average. However, with only the one interview I am not jumping to any rash conclusions. I do think that she will be a definite improvement.

Mr. Morris visited Saughnawage on Saturday afternoon, July 16th. I was quite favourably impressed and think that he should do much to improve the standard of our school.

The Building Changes.

I was at the agent's office yesterday when Mr. Doucet checked the plans for the Eastern School. Frankly, I was amazed that any person in the Architects Dept., could have been so ignorant of school construction. The plans were entirely different to those which Mr. Margreaves had sketched roughly while here.

The necessary work in the Eastern School could be completed within a month so I am hoping that the mistakes will be rectified more rapidly than the original plans were prepared.

As things stand at the moment there seems to be no hope whatsoever of having the new residence ready for September. There is a slim chance but it looks bad. Would it be possible for Mr. Brisebois to make temporary housing arrangements for the new staff sometime in the near future? If we wait until the last minute we will be unable to make any suitable boarding arrangements.

Sorry to be such a nuisance but time is flying.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Province
of Quebec, Electoral District of
Beauharnois-Laprairie

As you have been previously advised, we are converting one of the old brick schools formerly used by the Roman Catholic pupils into a four classroom school for the United Church children. Our proposals have been agreed to by both Churches, and we are now remodelling this school and installing electricity and plumbing so that it will be comparable with the new school being erected for the R.C. children.

In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, we advertised for tenders for the heating and plumbing installations required at the above school. These tenders covered the installation of lavatory and toilets throughout the buildings, as well as installation of an entire new heating system. Plans and specifications were prepared by engineers of the Lands & Development Services Branch.

Three tenders were obtained as a result of our advertisement, varying from the lowest sum of $9,500.00 to the highest of $12,035.00. We have checked with the heating engineer of the Lands & Development Services Branch, who advises that the lowest tender is fair and reasonable, and have, therefore, prepared a submission to Council covering acceptance of this lowest tender.

Director.

Attest.

Memorandum:

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Re: Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School

Alterations

It will be remembered that due to an error in the plans the alterations to the former Eastern R.C. School were delayed. The heating and plumbing were completed in good time but could not be operated because the electrical work was not provided for. The electrical plans were ready at the beginning of this month and the contract was awarded this week. As heating was necessary to protect the equipment, Mr. Beauvais, the local electrical contractor, was authorized to make temporary connections so that the heating plant could be operated.

There will be some extras at this school caused by the oversight of a sump pump for the furnace pit in the basement. The plans called for a pit approximately two feet deep to allow for the return. This excavation collects all overflow water and being so low cannot be drained except by means of an electrically operated pump.

Another extra is necessary for the septic tank. The plan on which the contractor bid would not operate due to the conditions of the soil. The school yard is quite level and a siphon as designated in the original plan could not operate. This was drawn to the attention of the Engineering Branch who prepared another plan which requires a small cabin to provide for the operation of the pump. These plans were delivered to me personally on the 9th of November and...
delivered to the contractor the following day. At this time the soil is frozen to approximately four inches. When the contractor bid on this it was to be summer work but because of this change, which is no fault of his, there will be surplus labour and also surplus equipment. The top of the soil will have to be broken by means of a compressor, rental of which I believe is $3.00 per hour. To estimate what these extras will be is very difficult, but the work should be followed very closely so that the expenditure will be kept at its minimum.

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Education.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Mr. Beaudry:

A position of Caretaker, Grade 6, was established for the Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec, with effect from November 1, 1949, in order that the services of a competent man might be secured to act as Caretaker of the new sixteen-room day school on the Caughnawaga Reserve. (Requisition No. IA-1073).

As it was the intention to fill this position as a result of a competition, temporary arrangements were made for the operation of the heating equipment, water system and electrical system. However, on January 11, 1950, when an Official from the Indian Affairs Branch Headquarters paid an inspectional visit to the Caughnawaga school, it was discovered that one of the motors had burned out and one of the boilers had been permitted to go dry.

As it was evident that the services of a man with the necessary qualifications were required immediately, Mr. Alfred K. Rice, an Indian of the Caughnawaga Reserve, was placed on duty on January 11, 1950.

As we have Mr. Rice's application on file here, I am forwarding it to you direct and advising Mr. F. Brisebois accordingly. It will be appreciated,

.............
therefore, if you will kindly issue the necessary Referral Form in favour of Mr. Wilfred W. Rice with effect from January 11, 1950.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Mr. Vernon M. Morris, principal at the local U.C. Indian Day School, advises, in writing, this morning that he had to dismiss two of the classes at his school this morning as the temperature was only 50 and 54.

When advised we immediately communicated with Mr. Rice, Chief Janitor, who called at that school and interviewed Mr. Morris.

It would appear that due to the fact that there is no automatic control to the boiler it is difficult to maintain an even temperature in this building. It is either too cold or too warm and in order to give satisfaction to the teachers it would require the full time of a man at that school as the Principal declines to have anything to do with the regulating of the furnace.

In order to remedy this situation Mr. Rice is suggesting that an automatic electric control be installed at that school. This could be done at an approximate price of $50.00 and would do doubt give satisfaction and at the same time save fuel.

Would you be kind enough to take this suggestion into consideration. Mr. Morris' letter is herewith enclosed.

(Fra. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
Jan. 25, 1950.

Dear Mr. Brisebois:

I have dismissed two of the rooms at the school this morning on account of cold rooms. In one room the temperature is 50° and the other 54°. My recent sick spell was caused by just this fact—the room cold in the morning and roasting in the afternoon—all times.

When the rooms are at a decent temperature—68° in the mornings we shall hold classes.

Yours truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Ottawa, May 4, 1950.

Col. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch.

I acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of the 28th ultimo, your file 304-5 (El), together with accounts for materials, amounting to some $10,109.28, for the renovation of the former Caughnawaga R.C. School to provide additional accommodation for the Caughnawaga U.C. Day School.

This matter was discussed with the Deputy Minister's Office, and in view of the total involved, I have been instructed to return the accounts to you and request that an Order-in-Council be secured to cover this expenditure.

We do not appear to have a requisition, or to have called for tenders for any of the material. No doubt the Branch secured some form of approval to proceed with this project. However, when the necessary Order-in-Council is secured then we will be in a position to place the usual confirming purchase order, so that the invoices can be placed in line for settlement.

H. E. Reaume.

Ottawa, July 5th, 1950.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School

Under separate cover we are forwarding you a memorandum regarding the renovation of the Caughnawaga U.C. School in order to provide living quarters for the teachers.

The memorandum of August 4th, 1949, pointed out that it was our intention to renovate the former "Eastern" School in order to provide the necessary classroom accommodation for the increased enrolment at the Caughnawaga U.C. School. The firm of Jean Bedard, Limited, were used to supervise the work and Indian labour was employed.

The Eastern School was also well constructed, but it was an old building, and consequently, as we proceeded with the renovation in order to provide three classrooms it was found necessary to purchase additional materials. As stated in my memorandum of concurrent date in connection with the conversion of the Caughnawaga U.C. School, the original order for materials was secured through the Departmental Purchasing Agent from Brais & Lecot. When additional materials were required they were also secured from the same firm, but Purchase Orders were not secured. This was due to the fact that we wanted the building finished at the earliest possible date, and the further fact that any interruption in the building operations would make it more difficult to secure labour when needed.

Departmental officials who have inspected the building feel that good value has been obtained for the money expended. The United Church officials who are interested in this school have expressed their approval of the provision that has been made for the education of Indian children who are adherents of the United Church.

......2
A report from Public School Inspector W.H. Brady dated May 27th, 1950, reads in part as follows:

"The school is now fully established in the building taken over. Repairs and redecoration, new furnace, new lighting system, new lavatories, etc., have made this a well appointed school, very bright and attractive."

I attach Memorandum to Council requesting authority to pay to Brais & Lanctot outstanding accounts amounting to $5,076.45.

Acting Director.
July 5th, 1950.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it was necessary to provide additional classroom accommodation for the pupils attending the Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School;

THAT it was decided that the most economical way to provide the increased accommodation would be to renovate the school building on the Caughnawaga Reserve formerly used by the Roman Catholic children known as the "Eastern School";

THAT while the Eastern School was a substantial building, it was built several years ago, and as work progressed it was found necessary to make several changes which were not at first anticipated;

THAT as a result it was found necessary to purchase additional materials from time to time as required, in order that the completion of the building would not be delayed.

THAT the cost of materials thus purchased amount to $5,076.45 from Brais & Lecotot, St. Isidore de Laprairie, P.Q.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for payment of $5,076.45 to Brais & Lecotot.

Funds are available in Vote 59, 1950-51, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, for payment of the amount mentioned above.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Ottawa, July 5th, 1950.

Re: Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Province
of Quebec, Electoral District of
Beauharnois-Laprairie

The construction of the Caughnawaga R.C. School
is nearing completion, and this building will be
ready for occupancy on September 1st.

As a result, the school building known as
"Caughnawaga Eastern School" will be vacated, and
as the present Caughnawaga U.C. School is too small,
we are making certain renovations to the Eastern
School to provide the extra classroom accommodation
that is required.

By vacating the present Caughnawaga U.C.
School we propose making renovations to convert this
building into a proper residence for the three
teachers who will be in charge of the school.
Departmental officials have visited the Caughnawaga
Reserve, and have prepared sketches of what is
required, and we are anxious to have these renovations
completed by September 1st if possible.

The Departmental Purchasing Agent is being
requested to secure the materials. The firm of Jean
Bedard, Limited, 480 Lafleur Street, Ville Lasalle,
P.Q., are prepared to supervise all the wood work,
engage the men required, and supply the services
of an engineer for an amount not exceeding $10.00 a
day. The total number of days this firm would be
employed would not exceed 40.
We understand that this is a very reliable firm and they can start work immediately. Enquiries were made in the vicinity of the Reserve by one of the officials from Head Office and by Superintendent Brisebois, but they were unable to locate anyone else who was prepared to start work immediately.

Under the circumstances, it would be appreciated if you would approve the employment of Jean Bedard, Limited.

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Caughnawaga U.C. Indian Day School

Under separate cover we are forwarding you a memorandum regarding the renovation of the Caughnawaga U.C. School in order to provide living quarters for the teachers.

The memorandum of August 4th, 1949, pointed out that it was our intention to renovate the former "Eastern" School in order to provide the necessary classroom accommodation for the increased enrolment at the Caughnawaga U.C. School. The firm of Jean Bedard, Limited, were used to supervise the work and Indian labour was employed.

The Eastern School was also well constructed, but it was an old building, and consequently, as we proceeded with the renovation in order to provide three classrooms it was found necessary to purchase additional materials. As stated in my memorandum of concurrent date in connection with the conversion of the Caughnawaga U.C. School, the original order for materials was secured through the Departmental Purchasing Agent from Brais & Lecotot. When additional materials were required they were also secured from the same firm, but Purchase Orders were not secured. This was due to the fact that we wanted the building finished at the earliest possible date, and the further fact that any interruption in the building operations would make it more difficult to secure labour when needed.

Departmental officials who have inspected the building feel that good value has been obtained for the money expended. The United Church officials who are interested in this school have expressed their approval of the provision that has been made for the education of Indian children who are adherents of the United Church.
A report from Public School Inspector W.H. Brady dated May 27th, 1950, reads in part as follows:

"The school is now fully established in the building taken over. Repairs and redecoration, new furnace, new lighting system, new lavatories, etc., have made this a well appointed school, very bright and attractive."

Ottawa, August 1, 1950.

Dear Sir:

Re: Conversion of U.C. Day School Building into Teachers' Residence, Caughnawaga.

Cheque 9711, dated July 21, 1950, for $7,662.48 was issued to Brais and Lanctot, St. Isidore, P.Q., in payment of general repairs made to a school building located on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

As this cost exceeds $5,000, would you advise me whether tenders were called and a contract awarded in the authorized manner?

It should be noted that encumbrance 958, for $7,822.48 is dated July 13, 1950, and would appear to have been prepared after receipt of the above account which begins under date of November 22, 1949. Examination of other accounts indicates that this is regular procedure, namely, have the work completed, then obtain a purchase order and an encumbrance immediately prior to submitting the account for payment.

I am of the opinion such procedures are not in accordance with Sections 26 and 29 of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act. The encumbrance should be forwarded to Treasury before the work begins and be based on estimated cost.

Yours truly,

R. G. Hamlyn,

OTTAWA, 19TH August, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

When Mr Delisle, teacher of the Caughnawaga Boys School, was in Ottawa last month, I had a long talk with him on school matters on that reserve, and he suggested that the best way to secure a better attendance would be to get the pupils interested by attracting them to the schools, and he said that this could be done by providing scholarships and giving a preference to children who attend regularly when drafting recruits for the Wikwemikong Industrial school. He considers that the scholarships should be sufficient to provide a college education for a certain number of the best pupils every year.

The school might be made more attractive by providing for the recreation of the pupils. He thinks that a toboggan slide would draw more pupils to the school than other means that could be devised.

The usual grant for prizes last year was not made as the application came in too late, and he recommends that this money be spent in the purchase of lumber for the erection of a slide on the school grounds, which could be used by both the boys and the girls.

Miss Street, who is in charge of the Girls school, thinks that this attraction would bring more pupils to the school than any enforcement of the regulations could possibly do. The parents are
averse to compelling their children to go, and if the school were made pleasant for them, they would naturally go of their own accord.

Mr Delisle has furnished an estimate of the improvements and repairs required for his school which includes a complete outfit of new desks, which the Inspector says are necessary. The Canada Office Furniture Co. of Montreal has given Mr Delisle a quotation of prices providing for 32 desks, one teacher's desk and chair, at a total cost of $156.20, which with the other work would bring the total cost up to placing the school in good shape, up to $178.30.

Modern desks are a necessity and if funds can be found for the purpose, I would recommend that they be supplied. It would be much better to purchase in Montreal than from Beauharnois, as was done when buying desks for the Girls school, which were said to have arrived in a damaged condition and only a few at a time.

Forty single desks were purchased last year for the Girls school but 15 more are required to provide seating capacity for the average number in attendance. A new stove is needed for the junior class room in this school as well as two wash stands and two small tables. The outlay for these articles would be about $75.00, making the total cost of re-fitting and furnishing both the Caughnawaga schools some to about $250.00.
Sir,

Veuillez donc me dire si le département a pris en considération les réclamations que je lui ai données au sujet de l'année blanche des écoles de Cap-Chatanaga ?

Si je peux m'attendre à ce que le département, outre pour cette fois même, manque d'attention et considère la bonne qualité des maîtres et la parfaitement exécute bien accomplit le Compte des Écoles.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Caughnawaga, Que.
Ottawa, February 17, 1912.

Sir,

The Principal of the Caughnawaga Boys' School reports that there has of late been a falling off in the attendance and that there are a large number of children on the reserve who are not enrolled at the school.

As you are aware a truant officer was appointed for the purpose of enforcing the regulations. I would ask you to have the Principal of the school provide Mr. Twoaxe with a list of those who are irregular in their attendance and also with a list of the children not enrolled. If the parents will not send these children to school regularly, Section 7 of the Regulations will have to be enforced. The Department will expect to receive at a later date a report from you as to the action taken and the results.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Asst. Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.
CAUGHNAWAGA,

St. CONSTANT, 2nd March, 1913

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Sir:-

Referring to your letter No 153652/1, dated the 17th Ultimo, in regard to the attendance of the children to the schools in Caughnawaga, I beg to say that the boys are attending their school in large numbers, there may be a certain number not enrolled yet on the Reserve, but those of the Village with a few exceptions for reason of sickness or unavoidable causes, are attending their school.

At the Girls' school the attendance is not what it should be during the winter, the attendance is irregular on account of more or less good reasons; the truant officer is trying to convince the parents to send their children at school more regularly, but this officer has not yet made a complaint against any of the parents.

According to the instructions mentioned in your letter I have notified the Principal of the boys school to provide Mr Twoaxe with a list of those who are irregular in their attendance to the school, and also with a list of the children not enrolled; I beg to ask you, if a complaint made by the truant officer and the warrant of arrest against some of the parents in default, are to be made verbally for the complaint, and simply a verbal order by the agent to arrest such parent?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Asst_Indian Agent,
